Supplement: A General Index to the Philosophical Transactions, from the First to the End of the Seventieth Volume

Author(s) Anonymous
Year 1780
Volume 70
Pages 805 pages
Language en
Journal Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
Download MD Download JSON View on JSTOR

Full Text (OCR)

A GENERAL INDEX TO THE PHILOSOPHICAL TRANSACTIONS, FROM THE FIRST TO THE END OF THE SEVENTIETH VOLUME. BY PAUL HENRY MATY, M.A. F.R.S. UNDER LIBRARIAN TO THE BRITISH MUSEUM. LONDON: PRINTED FOR LOCKYER DAVIS AND PETER ELMISLY, PRINTERS TO THE ROYAL SOCIETY. MDCCCLXXXVII AN ALPHABETICAL INDEX OF THE MATTER CONTAINED IN THE PHILOSOPHICAL TRANSACTIONS. A2 AN ALPHABETICAL INDEX TO THE PHILOSOPHICAL TRANSACTIONS The first column refers to the Transactions at large, and the other to the Abridgment. The Roman numbers denote the volume, and the Arabic figures the page. ABC ABD Abcess. Anatomical observations of an abcess in the liver; a great number of stones in the gall-bag and bilious vessels; an unusual conformation of the emulgents and pelvis; a strange conjunction of both kidneys and a great dilatation of the vena cava — Tyson XII 1035 III 81 Abdomen. An account of the dissection of a bitch whose cornua uteri, being filled with the bones and flesh of a former conception, had, after a second conception, the ova affixed to several parts of the abdomen — XIII 183 II 904 An account of a great quantity of hydatides found in the abdomen — Thorpe XXXI 17 An account of a dropfy in the left ovary of a woman aged 58, cured by a large incision made in the side of the abdomen — Houston XXXIII 8 VII 441 Extract of two uncommon cases of tumours in the abdomen, from a Latin tract published at Strafburg, anno 1728, and intitled Boecleri etc. ad Exteros Medicos Epistolae — Rutty XXXV 562 — 522 Case of a woman who had a foetus in her abdomen for nine years — Bromfield XLI 697 IX 191 A Case of a large quantity of matter or water contained in cystis's or bags adhering to the peritoneum, and not communicating with the cavity of the abdomen - Graham An improvement on the practice of tapping, whereby that operation, instead of a relief for symptoms, becomes an absolute cure for an ascites, exemplified in the case of Jane Roman - Warrick A Method of conveying liquors into the abdomen, during the operation of tapping - Hales Further accounts of the success of injecting medicated liquors into the abdomen, in the case of an ascites - Warrick Account of a child being taken out of the abdomen after having lain there upwards of 16 years - Myddleton A farther account of some experiments of injecting claret, &c., into the abdomen, after tapping - Warrick Account of an extraordinary steatomatous tumour in the abdomen of a woman - Hanley Aberration of the light of the fixed stars discovered - Bradley Of light refracted at spherical surfaces and lenses - Klingenskorne Theorem of the aberration of the rays of light refracted through a lens on account of the spherical figure - Maskelyne Phases of the transit of Venus, supposed to be retarded by the aberration of light - Winthorp On the effect of the aberration of light on the time of a transit of Venus over the sun - Price Absorbent (Earth's). An observation of the immoderate and fatal use of crab-stones, and such like absorbent earths, from whence have proceeded stones in the stomach and kidneys - Breynius Academy of Sciences. Part of a letter, giving an account of the new regulations of the Royal Academy of Sciences at Paris - Geoffrey Acceleration. A letter concerning the acceleration of the moon - Dunthorne Acemella. An account of the acemella and its stone-dissolving faculty - Hotton Acephalous. An account of a monstrous acephalous birth - Cooke Acid (Medical). A confirmation of the experiments made made by Sig. Fracassati in Italy, by injecting acid liquors into the blood — Boye The cure of a total suppression of urine, not caused by the stone, by the use of acids Baynard Experiments on the distillation of acids, volatile alkalies, &c. shewing how they may be condensed without loss, and how thereby we may avoid disagreeable and noxious fumes Woolf ACID (Animal). Account of an insect likely to yield an acid liquor — Lister Some experiments on a new animal acid Crellius ACID (Nitrous). Actual fire in detonation, produced by the contact of tin-foil, with the salt composed of copper and the nitrous acid Higgins ACIDULAE. Continuation of an experimental inquiry concerning the nature of the mineral elastic spirit or air contained in the Pouhon water, and other acidulae — Brownrigg ACOMACK. Relation of the effects of a violent storm at Acomack in America, Oct. 19, 1692, on the rivers of that country — Scarburgh ACORNS. A letter on the success of experiments for preserving acorns for a whole year, without planting them, so as to be in a state fit for vegetation, with a view to bring over some of the most valuable seeds from the East Indies, to plant for the benefit of our American Colonies — Ellis ACCOUNTS. Rules for correcting the usual methods of computing amounts and present values, by compound as well as simple interest; and of stating interest accounts — Watkins ACRES. A demonstration of the number of acres contained in England, or South Britain; and the use which may be made of it — Grew ACTINIA SOCIATA. An account of the actinia sociata, or clustered animal flower, lately found on the sea-coasts of the newly ceded islands — Ellis ADAMANT. On the particles and structure of adamant — Leeuwenhoek ADITS. An account how adits and mines are worked at Liege without air-shafts — Murray ÆTN. A chronological account of the several eruptions of Mount Ætna — Anon. An answer to some inquiries concerning the eruptions of Mount Ætna in 1669 A particular account of divers minerals, sent from the lately burning Mount Ætna - Anon. An extract of a letter concerning a late eruption of Mount Ætna, 1755 By the Magistrates of Mascali An account of a journey to Mount Ætna, 1769 Sir William Hamilton AFRICA. An account of a journey into, from the Cape of Good Hope Sparriar AGARIC OF OAK. Experiments concerning the use of the agaric of oak in stopping hemorrhages Sharp, Warner Some observations upon the agaric, lately applied after amputations, with regard to determining its species W. Watson Two letters concerning the use of agaric as a styptic Warner An account of a species of plant, from which the agaric, used as a styptic, is prepared W. Watson Extracts of two letters concerning the effects of the agaric of the oak, after some of the most capital operations in surgery Latterman An account of the success of agaric, and the fungus vinosus, in amputations Ford An account of the success of agaric in amputations Thornhill See Styptic and Lycoperdon. AGE. Part of a letter concerning a person who had a new set of teeth after 80 years of age; with some observations upon the virtues and properties of sugar Slare Two cases of persons cutting teeth in their old age Coleprese AGITATION. An account of an unusual agitation of the sea at Ilfracombe in Devonshire, Feb. 27, 1756 Prince AGNUS SCYTHICUS. An account of the Scythian vegetable Lamb, called Borametz Breynius AGRICULTURE. Enquiries proposed to be made concerning agriculture Committee of the Royal Society An account of a voyage to Chutan in China, with a description of the island, of the several sorts of tea, of the fishing, agriculture of the Chinese, &c., with several observations not hitherto taken notice of Cunningham A letter concerning the manuring of land with fossil-shells Pickering AGUE An account of the success of the bark of the willow in the cure of agues - Stone ANMELLA. Letter concerning Swammerdam's treatise de Apibus; the Anmella Ceylonensis, and the Faba S. Ignatii - Holton AIR (in general). Some trials about the air usually harboured and concealed in the pores of water - Boyle Some experiments shewing the difference of ice made without air, from that which is produced with air - Rinaldi An account of the increase of weight in oil of vitriol exposed to the air - Gauli An experiment, of a surprising change of colour from a pale transparent, or clear liquor, to a blue ceruleous-one, and that in an instant, by the admission of air only; applied to illustrate some changes of colour, and other effects on the blood of respiring animals - Stare Experiments concerning the effects of air passed through red-hot metals - Hauckbee An experiment concerning the nitrous particles in the air - Clayton A supposition how the white matter is produced which floats about in the air in autumn - Arderon A dissertation on the nature of evaporation, and several phenomena of air, water, and boiling liquors - Hamilton Observations on different kinds of air - Priestley A continuation of an experimental enquiry concerning the nature of the mineral elastic spirit, or air, contained in the Pouhon water, and other acidulae - Brownrigg An account of further discoveries in air - Priestley Experiments upon air, and the effects of different kinds of effluvia upon it - Whiz AIR (Appearances observed in the). An account of the appearance of several unusual parhelia, or mock suns; together with several circular arches lately seen in the air - Hall A letter from Annapolis in Maryland, containing an account of an explosion in the air - Lewis Two observations of explosions in the air, one heard at Halsted in Essex, the other at Springfield in the same county - Viewar and Shepheard An account of a meteor seen in the air in the daytime on Dec. 8, 1733 - Crocker An account of a fire-ball seen in the air, and of an explosion heard Dec. 11, 1741, near London Lord Beauchamp in Sussex - Fuller in Kent - Gofflin Account of a fiery meteor seen in the air July 14, 1745 - Caffard Dec. 16, 1742 - Meftines Letter concerning an explosion in the air, heard at Norwich in Jan. 7, 1750 - Arderon An account of a fire-ball seen in the air July 22, 1750 - Stukely Another account - Baker AIR (Damp).—An account of the damp air in a coal-pit of Sir James Lowther, Bart. sunk within 20 yards of the sea - Lowther An experiment to shew, that some damps in mines may be occasioned only by the burning of candles under ground, without the addition of any noxious vapours, even when the bottom of the pit has a communication with the outward air, unless the outward air be forcibly driven in at the said communication or pipe - Defaguliers A letter containing a short account of an explosion of air in a coal-pit at Middleton, near Leeds in Yorkshire - Bernard AIR (Density of the).—An account of an experiment touching the different densities of the air, from the greatest natural heat to the greatest natural cold in this climate - Hauksbee AIR (Effects of the, on animals) A comparison of the times, wherein animals may be killed by drowning in air, or withdrawing it - Boyle Of the accidents that happen to animals in air brought to a considerable degree, but not near the utmost one of rarefaction. - Boyle Of the observations produced in an animal in changes as to rarity and density made in the self-same air - Boyle Experiments on the necessity of air to the motion of ants and mites - Boyle A letter containing some considerations about the swimming bladders in fishes - Roy A conjecture concerning the bladders of air that are found in fishes, illustrated by an experiment suggested by the Hon. Robert Boyle - X 310 AIR The art of living under water; or a discourse concerning the means of furnishing air at the bottom of the sea, in any ordinary depths Halley Observations on a case published in the last volume of the Medical Essays, &c. of recovering a man dead in appearance, by distending the lungs with air Fothergill On the degree of salubrity of the common air at sea, compared with that of the sea-shore, and that of places far removed from the sea Ingen Houz AIR (Effects of the air when condensed or rarefied by the air-pump and condensing engine).—Proposals to try the effects of the pneumatick engine exhausted, on plants, seeds, eggs of fil-k-worms Beale Various experiments made in the exhausted receiver Boyle Some experiments made in the air pump at Paris by Papin, directed by Huygens Papin Some experiments made in the air pump upon plants, together with a way of taking exhausted receivers away from off the said engine. Papin and Huygens A continuation of the above experiments on the preservation of bodies Papin and Huygens Some experiments touching animals, made in the air pump Huygens and Papin Promiscuous experiments made in the air-pump Huygens and Papin An account of an experiment of shooting by the rarefaction of the air Papin A demonstration of the velocity wherewith the air rushes into an exhausted receiver Papin Concerning the application of an air-pump to cupping-glasses Luffkin Letter concerning the application of the pneumatick engine to cupping-glasses Luffkin Experiments on the infilling of bodies in common air in vacuo, and in air condensed Hawkbe AIR — An experiment on the descent of malt dust in an evacuated receiver — Hauksbee — An experiment shewing, that the seemingly spontaneous ascent of water in small tubes, open at both ends, is the same in vacuo as in the open air — Hauksbee — An account of an experiment, touching the difficulty of separating two hemispheres, upon the injecting of an atmosphere of air on their outward surfaces, without withdrawing the included air — Hauksbee — An account of the success of an attempt to continue several atmospheres of air condensed in the space of one, for a considerable time — Hauksbee — Experiments on animal fluids in the exhausted receiver — Darwin AIR (Elasticity and mechanical observations concerning) — An account how adits and mines are wrought at Liege without air-shafts — Moray — Experiments shewing that air, become unfit for respiration, may retain its wonted pressure — Boyle — Of its use to elevate the steams of bodies — Boyle — A table shewing to what degree air is compressible in sea water, from the depth of 1 foot to 1947 feet; useful to divers. Members of the Royal Society — Considerations touching the compresure of the air — Leeuwenhoek — Ten new experiments about the weakened spring, and some unobserved effects of the air — Boyle — A full description, with the use of a new contrivance for raising water — Papin — Answer to several objections made by Mr. Nevis against his engine for raising water by the rarefaction of the air — Papin — A discourse concerning the measure of the air's resistance to bodies moved in it — Wallis — An experiment shewing, that the springs or constituent parts of air are capable to suffer such disorder by a violent impulse, as to require time to recover their natural state — Hauksbee There are two pages of this No. in this vol. and this is the second. — Experiments concerning the time required in the descent of different bodies of different magnitudes tudes and weights in common air, from the same height Barometrical experiments for discovering the various elasticity of the air in different parts of Switzerland An account of some experiments made on the 27th of April, 1719, to find how much the resistance of the air retards falling bodies Further experiments An account of several experiments concerning the running of water in pipes, as it is retarded by friction and intermediate air, with a description of a new machine, whereby pipes may be cleared of air, as the water runs along, without hand-pipes, or the help of any hand An attempt made to shew how damps or foul air may be drawn out of any sort of mines, &c. by an engine An account of an instrument or machine for changing the air of the room of sick people in a little time, by either drawing out the foul air, or forcing in fresh air; or doing both successively, without opening doors or windows A calculation of the velocity of the air moved by a new-invented centrifugal bellows of 7 feet in diameter, and 1 foot thick within, which a man can keep in motion with very little labour, at the rate of two revolutions in one second The uses of the foregoing machine An account of an invention and method of changing the air in the hold, and other close parts of a ship Observations upon Mr. Sutton's invention to extract foul and stinking air out of ships, with critical remarks upon the use of windstalls An account of the great benefit of blowing showers of fresh air up through distilling liquors Thoughts on Dr. Hales's new method of distilling by the force of air and fire Air (Electricity of the). Observations upon the electricity of the air, made at the Chateau de AIR Maintenon in June, July, and October 1753 Air (Fixed). A Letter on the solubility of iron in simple water, by the intervention of fixed air The description of an apparatus for impregnating water with fixed air, and of the manner of conducting that process Air (Gravity and temperature of the). Letter containing particulars of a philosophical nature, viz. a narrative of the strange effects of thunder upon a magnetic card; some remarks concerning the gradual alteration of the temperature of the air in divers countries; a contrivance of an uncommon hygroscope; the musky scent of certain parts of the animal called the musk-quash A discourse concerning the air's gravity A letter giving an account of several observations in Virginia and in his voyage thither, more particularly concerning the air Second letter of farther observations on Virginia An account of an experiment, touching the proportion of the weight of air, to the weight of a like bulk of water, without knowing the quantity of either An observation of extraordinary warmth of the air in January 1741 On the correspondence of the barometer with the air and weather Remarks on the heat of the air in July 1757 Additional remarks An account of the extraordinary heat of the weather in July 1757, and of the effects of it Remarks on the different temperature of the air at Eddystone, from that observed at Plymouth, between the 7th and 14th of July 1757 An investigation of the difference between the present temperature of the air in Italy and some other countries, and what it was seventeen centuries ago An account of a most extraordinary degree of cold AIR cold at Glasgow in January 1780; together with some new experiments and observations on the comparative temperature of hoar-frost, and the air near to it, made at Glasgow - Wilson AIR (History of the). A physical history of the earth and air for the year 1732 - Cyrilus AIR (Inflammable). A chemical experiment, serving to illustrate the phenomenon of inflammable air, shewn to the Royal Society by Sir James Lowther, and described in the Transactions, No 429 - Mau Account of a new kind of inflammable air or gas, which can be made in a moment without apparatus, and is as fit for explosion as other inflammable gases in use for that purpose; together with a new theory of gunpowder - Ingen-Housz Experiments and observations on the inflammable air breathed by various animals - Fontana AIR (Nitrous). Easy methods of measuring the diminution of bulk taking place upon the mixture of common air and nitrous air; together with experiments on platina - Ingen-Housz AIR (Production of). An account of an experiment to try the quality of air produced from gunpowder, fired in vacuo Boyliano - Hauksbee An account of an experiment touching the quantity of air produced from a certain quantity of gunpowder fired in common air - Hauksbee Three papers containing experiments on factitious air - Cavendish Account of the airs extracted from different kinds of waters; with thoughts on the salubrity of the air at different places - Fontana AIR (Promiscuous properties of). Observations on several passages in the Transactions, relating to some unobserved qualities of the air; to the mixing fermenting liquors in vacuo; to the history of birds; the anatomy of the trunks of vegetables, baroscopes, &c. - Anon. An experiment touching the freezing of common water, and water purged of air - Hauksbee An experiment touching the weighing of bodies of the same species, but of very unequal sur- faces in common water, being of an equal weight in common air Air (Refraction of the). An experiment of the refraction of the air, made at the command of the Royal Society — Some allowances to be made in astronomical observations for the refraction of the air, with an accurate table of refractions Air-Pump. An account of some improvements in the air-pump — An account of some experiments made with an air-pump on Mr. Smeaton's principle; together with some experiments with a common air-pump Albatenius. Emendations and notes upon the ancient astronomical tables of Albatenius, with the restoration of his lunar tables Alcali. Two letters, giving an account of a red colour produced by mixture of a sulphureous spirit with a volatile alcali Alcaline Salts. A dissertation on fixed alcaline salts — Continued — A chemical experiment of the effect of quicklime upon volatile alcaline — Experiments on the distillation of acids, volatile alkalies, &c. shewing how they may be condensed without loss, and how thereby to avoid disagreeable and noxious fumes See Salt. Alcanna. Concerning rusina and alcanna Phil. Soc. Oxf. Aldebaran. An observation of the moon's transit by Aldebaran, Apr. 3, 1736 — An occultation of Aldebaran by the Moon, Dec. 12, 1738 Aleppo. A relation of a voyage from Aleppo to Palmyra in Syria Alga. Observations on the sea alga with broad leaves Algebra. Thoughts about some defects in algebra — A treatise of algebra, both historical and practical — A correction of the 109th chapter of Wallis's algebra — An instance of the excellence of the modern al- gebra in the resolution of the problem of finding the foci of optick-glasses universally Holley A second letter concerning the roots of equations, with the demonstration of other rules in algebra MacLaurin An algebraic problem, and of the evolution of a certain mechanic curve amongst infinite hyper-mechanical ones, which resolve a certain equation (Lat.) Fontoni Observations on the limits of algebraical equations; and a general demonstration of Des Cartes's rule for finding their number of affirmative and negative roots Milne On the general resolution of algebraical equations Waring See Equations. See Opticks. ALHAZEN. Letters between M. Slusius and M. Hugenius relative to an optic problem of Alhazen. ALICANT. See Snap. ALIMENT. An account of the bones of animals being changed to a red colour by aliment only Belchier A further account of the bones of animals being made red by aliment only Belchier ALLANTOIS. The humane allantois fully discovered; and the reasons assigned why it has not hitherto been found out, even by those who believed its existence; with an answer to their objections who deny it still Hall ALLIGATOR. An account of the fossil bones of an alligator, found on the sea-shore near Whitby in Yorkshire Chapman Another account of the same Woolley ALOE AMERICANA SERRATI-FOLIA. An experiment on Aloe Americana Serrati-folia weighed, seeming to import a circulation of the sap in plants ALUM. A description of a Swedish stone, which affords sulphur, vitriol, alum, and minium Tabst A continuation of the discourse concerning vitriol, shewing, that vitriol is usually produced by sulphur, acting on, and coagulating with, a metal; and then making cut, that alum is likewise the result of the said sulphur; as also evincing, that vitriol, sulphur, and alum, do agree in the saline principles: and, lastly, de- claring the nature of the salt in brimstone, and whence it is derived **Alum-Works.** An account of the English alum-works **Alphabet.** An essay towards a universal alphabet, and new primer — A letter containing some remarks on Mr. Lodwick's alphabet — Further remarks upon M. l'Abbé Barthelemy's Memoir on the Phoenician letters; containing his reflections on certain Phoenician monuments, and the alphabets resulting from them **Alpine Mouse.** The anatomy of the Alpine mouse — A short natural history of the Alpine mouse (Lat.) **Altar (Roman).** Account of a Roman altar found at Chester — An account of two Roman altars lately found in the North of England, with notes, by Tho. Gale — An attempt to explain two Roman inscriptions, cut upon two altars, which were dug up sometime since at Bath — The inscription upon a Roman altar found near Stanhope, in the bishoprick of Durham — An account of a Roman altar, with an inscription upon it, found in April last at York, and communicated to the Society of Antiquaries by F. Drake; as also a brief explication of the inscription by John Ward **Alternations.** The doctrine of combinations and alternations improved and compleated **Altitude.** Table of the barometrical altitudes at Zurich in Switzerland, in the year 1708, by Scheuchzer; and at Upminster in England, by Derham; as also the rain at Pisa in Italy, in 1707 and 1708, by Tilli; and at Zurich in 1708; and at Upminster in all that time: with remarks on the same tables; as also on the winds, heats, colds, and divers other matters occurring in those three parts of Europe **Altitudes.** The description of a new quadrant for taking altitudes, without an horizon, either at sea or land Account of a spirit-level to be fixed to a quadrant for taking a meridional altitude at sea, when the horizon is not visible - Hadley A description of a water-level to be fixed to Davis's quadrant for taking the sun's altitude at sea in thick and hazy weather without an horizon - Leigh The description and use of an apparatus, added as an improvement to Davis's quadrant, consisting of a mercurial level, for taking the co-altitude of sun or star at sea, without the usual assistance of the sensible horizon, which frequently is obscured - Leigh A new method of finding time by equal altitudes - Aubert An account of the apparatus applied to the equatorial instrument, for correcting the errors arising from the refraction in altitude - Dollond AMALGAM. On the use of an amalgam of zinc, for the purpose of electrical excitation - Higgins AMAND. (St.) MINERAL WATERS. Letter concerning the mineral waters of St. Amand, near Tournay and Valenciennes - Geoffry AMBE. The ambe of Hippocrates, for reducing luxations of the arm with the shoulder, rectified - M. le Cot AMBER. Account of a curious piece of Hevelius An observation about white amber - Kirkho A compendious history and demonstration of the Prussian amber - Hartmann An account of several curiosities relating to amber - Hartmann A Treatise on amber - Camell Experiments on the luminous qualities of amber, diamonds, and gumlac - Walli An observation of a piece of amber with a leaf of a plant impressed on it - Breynius An extract from a letter on the nature of amber - Beurer Extract from an essay on the origin of amber - Fothergill AMBERGREASE. Letter concerning ambergrace, and its being a vegetable production - Boyle An account of a great piece of ambergrace, thrown on the island of Jamaica - Fredway Found in whales - Boyston An essay upon the natural history of whales, with a particular account of the ambergrise found in the spermaceti whales Dudley XXXIII 256 VII 424 A treatise on ambergrise, Par. I Neumann XXXVIII 344 IX 339 Par. II Neumann — 371 — 346 Par. III Neumann — 417 — 358 A review of the experiments on ambergrise made by Messrs. Browne and Hanckewits, by Dr. Martine, with Mr. Neumann's vindication of his own experiment Neumann — 437 — 366 AMERICA. A narrative of some observations made upon several voyages to find a way for sailing about the North to the East Indies, and for returning the same way from thence hither; together with the instruction given by the Dutch East India Company for the discovery of Jeffo, near Japan. To which is added, a relation of sailing through the northern America to the East Indies Von Nieorp IX 197 Some observations concerning a possible passage to the East Indies by the Northern America, Westward Anon. — 207 An account of that part of America which is nearest to the land of Kamtchatka; extracted from the description of Kamtchatka, by professor Krafftencoff Dumaresque LI 477 A dissertation on the bones and teeth of elephants, and other beasts, found in North America, and other Northern regions; by which it appears they are the bones of indigenous beasts Rafse LIX 126 Observations of eclipses of Jupiter's first satellite at Greenwich, compared with observation of the same made by Samuel Holland in North America, and the longitudes of places thence deduced Muskelyne LXIV 184 Immersions and emersions of Jupiter's first satellites observed at Jupiter's inlet, on the island of Anticosti, North America, and the longitude of the place deduced from comparison with observations made at the Royal Observatory at Greenwich, by the Astronomer Royal Wright AMIANTHUS. A curious relation, taken out of the third Venetian journal de Letterati, of a substance found in great quantities in some mines of Italy; out of which is made a kind of combustible substance, both skin, paper, and candle. candle-wick, together with some experiments made therewith AMIANTHUS. See Asbestos. AMLWCH WATERS. An account of the vitriolic waters of Amlwch, in the isle of Anglesey AMMONITÆ. A letter concerning some vertebrae of ammonitæ, or cornua ammonis AMNI LIQUOR. Some observations, proving that the fetus is in part nourished by the liquor Amnii AMOMUM. A description and figure of the true Amomum, or Tugus of the Philippines AMOUNTS. Rules for correcting the usual methods of computing amounts and present values by compound, as well as simple interest; and of stating interest-accounts AMPHIBIOUS ANIMALS. An account of an amphibious biped — — A supplement to the account of an amphibious biped, being the anatomical description of the said animal — Observations upon animals, commonly called amphibious by authors — An account of the lymphatic system in amphibious animals AMPUTATION. A letter concerning the use of Lycoperdon in stopping blood after amputation — An account of the success of Agaric, and Fungus Vinosus, upon amputations — Remarks and considerations relative to the performance of amputation above the knee, by the single circular incision — See Agaric, Fungus Vinosus, Lycoperdon and Styptic. ANALYSIS. Experiments by way of analysis upon the water of the dead sea, upon the hot springs near Tiberiades, and upon Hamman Pharoan water ANALYTICAL. Universal solution for quadratic and biquadratic equations, viz. analytical, geometrical, and mechanical — Analytical solution of certain infinitesimal equations ANASTOMOSES. An account of some uncommon anastomoses of the spermatic vessels in a woman ANATOMY. ANATOMY OF VEGETABLES. Observations on several passages in the two last months Transactions relating to some unobserved qualities of the air; to mixing and fermenting liquors in vacuo; to the history of birds; the anatomy of the trunks of vegetables; baroscopes, &c. Experiments concerning the encaustic paintings of the ancients - Colebrook Ll 40 A letter concerning the success of the former experiments - Colebrook - 53 Some observations concerning the lyncurium of the ancients - William Watson - 394 Some attempts to ascertain the utmost extent of the knowledge of the ancients in the East-Indies - Gaverhill LVII 155 ANDERIDA. An account of an extraordinary aneurism of the arteria aorta near the basis of the heart, with the symptoms thereof An account of an aneurism of the aorta Some observations on aneurisms in general, and in particular on the foregoing A remarkable case of an aneurism, or disease of the principal artery of the thigh, occasioned by a fall. To which is prefixed, a short account of the uncertainty of the distinguishing symptoms. Concerning aneurisms in the thigh ANGLE. A direct and geometrical method by which the aphelia, eccentricities, and proportion of the orbs of the primary planets, may be investigated without supposing the equality of the angle of motion at the other focus of the planet's ellipsis An account of an experiment concerning the angle required to suspend a drop of oil of oranges, at certain stations, between two glass planes, placed in the form of a wedge A new universal method of describing all curves of every order mechanically, by the assistance of angles and right lines Solution of the problem relating to the invention of curves, which, disposed in a certain manner in an inverse situation, may cut each other in a given angle Of the section of an angle A description of a new instrument for taking angles An account of observations made on board the Chatham yacht August 30th, and September 1st, 1732, for the trial of an instrument for taking angles A description of a contrivance for measuring small angles An explanation of a new instrument made for measuring small angles Account of a new instrument for measuring small angles, called the Prismatic Micrometer See Micrometer. ANGLESEY. See Population. ANIMALS (in General). Description of a microscope, by the means whereof there has been seen an animal lesser than any of those hitherto seen Observations of some animals, and of a strange plant, made in a voyage into the kingdom of Congo. M. Ang. de Guattini, and Dionysius of Placenza. Microscopical observations about animals in the scurf of the teeth; the substance called worms in the nose; the cuticula consisting of scales Lumbricus Hydropicus; or an essay to prove that the hydatides, often met with in morbid animal bodies, are a species of worms, or imperfect animals Letters concerning the seeds of plants, with observations on the manner of the propagation of plants and animals An account of an animal resembling a whelp voided per anus by a male greyhound Remarks on some animals, plants, &c. sent from Maryland An account of some animals sent from the East Indies, with remarks by J. Petiver Account of more animals Account of more animals observed in the Philippine Islands A new division of terrestrial brute animals, particularly of those that have their feet formed like hands; where an account is given of some animals not yet described An account of animals and shells sent from Carolina An account of the animals in the Philippine Islands Observations on the mouths of the eels in vinegar, and also a strange aquatic animal A description of the female musk animal, by the Jesuits at skin An account of worm in animal bodies Observations on coralline, and the polypus, and other sea animals Remarks on the above observations Observations on noxious animals in England ANIMAL FLOWERS. Malpighi and Fracossati An account of some animals that, having lungs, are yet found to be without the arterious vein; together with some other curious particulars. Swammerdam An abstract of a letter concerning the parts of brain of several animals, the chalk-stones of the gout, the leprosy, and the scales of eels. Leeuwenhoek An extract of a letter containing several observations on the texture of the bones of animals, compared with that of wood. Leeuwenhoek An essay upon the use of the bile in the animal economy, founded on an observation of a wound in the gall-bladder. Stuart Explanation of an essay on the use of the bile in the animal economy. Stuart ANIMALS (Experiments on).—An experiment of preserving animals alive, by blowing through their lungs with bellows. Hook Account of two animals included with large wounds in the abdomen in the pneumatical receiver. Boyle Of the motion of the separated heart of a cold animal in the exhausted receiver. Boyle A comparison of the times wherein animals may be killed by drowning, or withdrawing of the air. Boyle Of the accidents that happen to them in air brought to a considerable degree, but not near the utmost one, of rarefaction. Boyle Of the observations produced in an animal in changes, as to rarity and density made in the self-same air. Boyle Of an unsuccessful attempt to prevent the necessity of respiration by the production or growth of animals in our vacuum. Boyle Of the power of assuofaction to enable animals to hold out in air by rarefaction made unfit for respiration Boyle V 2045 Some experiments, touching animals, made in the air-pump Huygens and 446 Of the heat of animals and vegetables John Hunter LXVIII 7 Experiments and observations on the inflammable air breathed by several animals Fontana LXIX 337 Animals (Ditord rs of).—Some observations on the motion of ctenates, and on the births and deaths of man, and other animals in different times of the Noxbriger Pasteur XVII 815 III 311 Of an obstruction of the biliary ducts, and an impostumation of the gall-bladder, discharging upwards of 18 quarts of bilious matter in 25 days, without any apparent defect in the animal functions. **Animal (Fossil).**—An account of the impression of the almost entire skeleton of a large animal in a very hard stone found at Elston, near Newark, Nottinghamshire. An account of a pair of very extraordinary large horns found in Wapping some years since; with a probable account whence they came, and to what animal they belonged. An account of a fossil thigh-bone of a large animal dug up at Stone's-field, near Woodstock, in Oxfordshire. See Fossil Generation. **Animal Juices.** See Juices. **Animalcula.** Observations concerning some little animals observed in rain, well, sea, and snow-water; as also in water where pepper had lain infused. Observed in Semine Humano. Concerning animalcula found in the teeth. Several observations and experiments on the animalcula in pepper-water. Some microscopical observations of vast numbers of animalcula seen in water. Answer to the objections made to Leeuwenhoek's opinions concerning the animalcula in semine in masculino. Concerning the animalcula in semine humano. Further observations on the animalcula in semine masculino. Several microscopical observations and experiments concerning the animalcula in semine masculino of cocks and spiders. Letter concerning green weeds growing in water, and animalcula found about them. ANIMALCULA. Two letters from a gentleman in the country relating to Observations on some animalcula in water A letter concerning animalcula, on the roots of duck weed Part of a letter concerning some microscopical observations upon the animalcula in seminal of young rams A letter containing some further microscopical observations on the animalcula found upon duck-weed Observations on a particular manner of increase in the animalcula of vegetable infusions, with the discovery of an indissoluble salt arising from hemp-seed put into water till it becomes putrid ANNUITIES. An estimate of the degrees of the mortality of mankind, drawn from curious tables of the births and funerals at the city of Breslaw; with an attempt to ascertain the price of annuities upon lives The easiest method of calculating the value of annuities upon lives from tables of observations A letter concerning the value of an annuity for life, and the probability of survivorship A letter concerning the method of constructing a table for the probabilities of life at London A letter with a table of the value of annuities on lives A letter concerning the term and period of human life: in which the inequalities in constructing, and the false conclusions drawn from Dr. Halley's Breslaw table, are fully proved; the supposed extraordinary healthfulness of that place is particularly examined, and confuted; and its real state shewn to be equalled by divers places in England; the imperfection of all the tables formed upon 1000 lives shewn; and a method proposed to obtain one much better Observations on the expectations of lives, the increase of mankind, the influence of great towns on population, and particularly the state of London with respect to healthfulness and number of inhabitants **Price** **ANNUITIES.** Short and easy theorems for finding, in all cases, the differences between the values of annuities payable yearly, and of the same annuities payable half-yearly, quarterly, or monthly **Price** **ANNULUS.** See Saturn. **ANOMALIES.** Considerations concerning Mercator's geometric and direct method for finding the apogees, excentricities, and anomalies of the planets **Mercator** **ANOMALY.** See Planet. **ANTHELIUM.** Observation on an anthelium seen at Witenberg Jan. 17-8, 1738 (Lat.) **Weidler** — An account of an anthelium observed near Oxford July 24, varying the apparent distance of the moon from the sun or a star; also an easy rule of approximation for computing the distance of the moon from a star, the longitudes and latitudes of both being given, with demonstrations of the same **APPULSES.** Appulses of the moon to Saturn, and the fixed stars observable in the year 1671 foretold, and reduced to the meridian and latitude of London stars, predicted for 1674 An advertisement to astronomers, of the advantages that may accrue from the observations of the moon's frequent appulses to the Hyades, during the course of the three next ensuing years On the method of determining the places of the planets, by observing their near appulses to the fixed stars A new method of calculating eclipses, particularly of the earth, and of any Extract of a letter concerning the art of to lay children in, to preserve them from being overlaid — St. John AREA. A new experiment concerning an effect of the varying weight of the atmosphere upon some bodies in the water The barometrical method of measuring the heights of mountains, with two new tables shewing the height of the atmosphere at given altitudes of Mercury An astronomical dissertation on the lunar atmosphere Some observations of the planet Venus, on the disk of the sun, June 6, 1761; with a preceding account of the method taken for verifying the time of that phenomenon; and certain reasons for believing there is an atmosphere about Venus Dunn Certain reasons for a lunar atmosphere Dunn Theorems concerning the electrical atmosphere Baccaria A letter inclosing an account of some observations on atmospherical electricity; in regard to fog, mists, &c. with some remarks Ronayne Extraordinary electricity of the atmosphere observed at Islington in October 1775 Cavalli Observations on the annual evaporation at Liverpool, in Lancashire, and on evaporation considered as a test of the moisture or dryness of the atmosphere Dobson Observations made in Savoy in order to ascertain the height of mountains by means of the barometer; being an examination of Mr. de Luc's rules, delivered in his "Recherches sur les Modifications de l'Atmosphere" Shuckburgh See Air. Attraction. A letter in which the laws of attraction, and other principles of physic, are shewn Keill A vindication of Dr. Freind's chemical lectures, wherein the objections (in Actis Lipiensibus, Sept. 1710) brought against the attractive force of matter are removed Freind An account of an experiment in order to discover the law of the magnetical attraction Taylor and Hawkbee Experiments and observations upon the light that is produced by communicating electrical attraction to animal or inanimate bodies, together with some of its most surprising effects Gray Investigations to prove that the figure of the earth nearly approaches to an ellipsis, according to the laws of attraction, in an inverse ratio of the square of the distances Clairault A resolution of a general proposition for determining the horary alteration of the position of the terrestrial equator from the attraction of the sun and moon, with some remarks on the solutions given by other authors to that difficult and important problem Simpson Of the irregularities in the planetary motions, caused by the mutual attraction of the planets A proposal for measuring the attraction of some hills in this kingdom by astronomical observations An account of observations made on the mountain Schehallien for finding its attraction On the precession of the equinoxes produced by the sun's attraction Calculations to determine at what point in the side of a hill its attraction will be the greatest Attrition. Several experiments on the attrition of bodies in vacuo An account of an experiment touching the extraordinary electricity of glass produceable on a smart attrition of it; with a continuation of experiments on the same subject, and other phenomena Several experiments shewing the strange effects of the effluvia of glass, produceable on the motion and attrition of it An account of some experiments touching the electricity and light produceable in the attrition of several bodies An account of an experiment shewing, that an object may become visible through such an opake body as pitch in the dark, while it is under the circumstances of attrition and a vacuum Aurora Australis. Experiments to shew the nature of Aurum Mosaicum - Woulfe AVERDUPOISE. An account of a comparison lately made by some gentlemen of the Royal Society of the standard of a yard, and the several weights lately made for their use, with the original standards of measures and weights in the Exchequer, and some others kept for public use, at Guildhall, Founders-hall, the Tower, &c. - Graham A state of the English weights and measures of capacity, as they appear from the laws, as well antient as modern, with some considerations thereon; being an attempt to prove that the present averdupoise weight is the legal and antient standard for the weights and measures of this kingdom - Reynardson Short and easy methods for finding the number of troy pounds, contained in any given number of averdupoise pounds, and vice versa - Ferguson AVERNI. En extract of an essay entitled, 'On the uses of a knowledge of mineral exhalations when applied to discover the principles and properties of mineral waters, the nature of burning fountains, and of those poisonous lakes which the antients called Averni' - Brownrigg AUSTRIA. Remarks on the second paper in the history of the Royal Academy of Sciences for 1711, concerning the cause of the variation of the barometer; to shew that the way of accounting for it in that paper is insufficient, and that the experiment made use of to prove what is there asserted, does no way prove it. An account of the death and dissection of John Bayles, of Northampton, reputed to have been 130 years old — Keil BEANS. An account of four sorts of strange beans frequently cast on shore on the Orkney Islands, with some conjectures about the way of their being brought thither from Jamaica, where three sorts of them grow — Sloane BEASTS. A dissertation on the bones and teeth of elephants, and other beasts found in America, and other northern regions, by which it appears they are the bones of indigenous beasts — Raspe BEATIFICATION. Letter declaring that Dr. Watson, as well as many others, have not been able to make odours pass through glass by means of electricity; and giving a particular account of professor Bon's experiment or beatification, or causing a glory to appear round a man's head by electricity — W. Watson BEAUCASTLE. See Inscription. BIRTH. An account of an extraordinary birth in Staffordshire — Birch Some observations on the motion of diseases, and on the births and deaths of men and other animals, in different times of the year — Paschall An argument for Divine Providence; taken from the constant regularity observed in the births of both sexes — Arbuthnot An account of an extraordinary acephalous birth — Cooper See Child, Monster. BITCH. An account of the dissection of a bitch, whose cornua uteri, being filled with the bones and flesh of a former conception, had, after a second conception, the ova affixed to several parts of the abdomen — Anon. An account of the cutting out the cæcum of a bitch — Mulgrave BITE. Microscopical observations of the structure of teeth and other bones - Leeuwenhoek Part of two letters concerning a prodigious Os Frontis in the Medicine School at Leyden - Molyneux An extract of a letter containing several observations on the texture of the bones of animals compared with that of wood - Leeuwenhoek Osteographia Elephantina; or a full and exact description of all the bones of an elephant, with their several dimensions: to which are premised, an historical account of the natural endowments and several wonderful performances of elephants, with the manner of taking and taming them. An anatomical account of their parts, &c. - Blair Observations upon the bones and the periosteum - Leeuwenhoek An account of a praeter-natural bony substance found in the cavity of the thorax - Rutty An account of a large bony substance found in the womb, 1733 - Hody An account of the bones of animals being changed to a red colour by aliment only - Belchier A further account of the bones of animals being made red by aliment only - Belchier A picture of the size of a gigantic bone; with a problem for determining the size of the giant according to the rules of the art of drawing - Klein Observations and experiments with madder root, which has the faculty of tinging the bones of living animals of a red colour - Du-Monceau An account of tumours which rendered the bones soft - Pott An account of a large piece of the thigh-bone, which was taken out and its place supplied by a callus - Richardson An account of an extraordinary case of the bones of a woman growing soft and flexible - Bevan The case of a young child at Houghton, in Huntingdonshire, born with all its bones displaced - Davi Case of Anne-Elizabeth Queriot of Paris, whose bones were distorted and softened Holly XLVIII 26 A remarkable case of fragility, flexibility, and dissolution of the bones Pringle — 297 Case of William Carey, aged 19, whose tendons and muscles were turned into bones Henry LI 89 Further account Henry — 92 An account of a bone found in the pelvis of a man at Brussels Brady — 660 A further account of the case of William Carey, whose muscles began to be ossified Henry LII 143 A account of the extraction of three inches and ten lines of the bone of the upper arm, which was followed by a regeneration of the bony matter; with a description of a machine made use of to keep the upper and lower pieces of the bone at their proper distances, during the time that the regeneration was taking place; and which may also be of service in fractures happening near the head of that bone Le Cat LVI 370 Bones (Fossil). An account of a very sudden and excessive swelling of a woman's breasts — A letter concerning the death of the big-breasted woman, together with what was observed on her body — Letter giving an account why the big-breasted woman was not opened after her death — Case of one who swallowed a knife, which lay in his stomach a year and 7 months, and then washed out at an apothecary on his breast — Account of a child born with a large wound in the breast, supposed to arise from the force of imagination — The case of Mary Howell, who had a needle run into her arm, which came out at her breast Breathing. Letter concerning the cause of the necessity of breathing Breeding. See Sap. Briderkirk. See Inscription. Bridewell at Norwich. Extract of a letter concerning the antient bridewell at Norwich Bridge. Letter concerning the bridge of St. Esprit in France — A further account, with a parallel history of some other bridges at Rome — Description of a bridge that may be built 70 feet long, without any pillar under it — Problems concerning the fall of water under bridges; applied to the falls under London and Westminster bridges Bridgnorth. An extract of a topographical account of Bridgnorth, in the county of Salop BRIGHT. Letter concerning Mr. Bright, the extraordinary fat man at Malden, in Essex Anon. BRIMSTONE. Of the mineral of Liege, yielding both brimstone and vitriol, and the way of extracting them out of it, used at Liege Anon. — A continuation of the discourse concerning vitriol, shewing, that vitriol is usually produced by sulphur, acting on, and coagulating with, a metal; and then making out, that allum is likewise the result of the said sulphur; as also evincing, that vitriol, sulphur, and allum, do agree in the saline principles; and, lastly, declaring the nature of the salt in brimstone, and whence it is derived Anon. — Extract of two letters concerning the effects of a cane of black sealing-wax and a cane of brimstone in electrical experiment Miles — Observations made on the brimstone-hill in the island of Guadeloupe Peyssonel BRISTLE. An account of a bristle that was lodged in a gentleman's foot, and caused a violent inflammation Arderon BRISTOL WATER. Observations on the heat of Bristol waters Canton BRITAIN. A letter giving an account of tulips, and such bulbous plants, flowering much sooner when their bulbs are placed upon bottles filled with water, than when planted in the ground — An account of the same experiments tried the next year by — Experiments and observations on bulbous roots, plants, and seeds growing in water BULK. Specific gravity of several metalline cubes, in comparison with their like bulks of water — An account of an experiment to shew by a new proof, that bodies of the same bulk do not contain equal quantities of matter, and therefore that there is an interspersed vacuum BUL Bulk. LIII. **Channel.** An advertisement necessary for all navigators bound up the channel of England - Anon. **Characters.** A letter containing the exact draughts of several unknown characters, taken from the ruins at Persepolis - Flowers A paper containing some unknown antient characters, with remarks thereon, by Francis Aston, Esq. - Flowers An explanation of the figures of a Pagan temple, and unknown characters, at Cannara in Salset - Stuart An explanation of the Runic characters of Kel-singland - Celsius Extract of a letter concerning a supposed connection between the hieroglyphical writing of antient Egypt, and the characteristic writing which is in use at this day among the Chinese - Morton See China. **Charcoal.** Experiments and observations on charcoal - Priestley Extract of a letter on some electrical experiments made with charcoal - Kinnersley Account of the manner in which the Russians treat persons affected by the fumes of burning charcoal, and other effluvia of the same nature. **CHARM.** Conjectures on the charming or fascinating power attributed to the rattle-snake; grounded on credible accounts, experiments, and observations. **CHARR-FISH.** Some account of the charr-fish, as found in North Wales. **CHARTS.** Some remarks on the variation of the magnetic compass, published in the memoirs of the Academy of Sciences, with regard to the general chart of those variations made by E. Roger Clarke, of his majesty's sloop the Otter, with a plane chart of the coast. **CHARTHAM.** See Bones. **CHEEK.** An account of an extraordinary tumour or wen lately cut off the cheek of a person in Scotland. — Account of a rottenness of the cheek-bone, occasioned by a vast quantity of matter flowing from the mouth of a boy for three years. **CHEESE.** Observations on insects bred in cheese, &c., by **CHELIDONIUM MAJUS.** A letter concerning the tubes or canals that convey the yellow sap in the herb called Chelidonium Majus, or Celandine. **CHERRY TREES.** An experiment of making cherry-trees, that have withered fruit, to bear full and good fruit; and of recovering the almost-withered fruit Cheshire. Some observations on an incited Greek coin of Philistis queen of Syracuse, Malta, and Gozo, who had been passed over in silence by all the ancient writers COLD ANIMAL. See Animal. COLD (CHEMISTRY). A new frigorific experiment, shewing how a considerable degree of cold may be produced without the help of snow, ice, hail, wind, or nitre, and that at any time of the year An account of some experiments relating to the production of fire and flame; together with an explosion made by a mixture of two liquors actually cold Observations upon the dissolutions and fermentations, which we may call cold, because they are accompanied with a coolness of the liquors into which they pass COLD (DISEASE). Some suggestions for remedies against cold Historical account of the late general coughs and colds, with some observations on other epidemical distempers Extract of a letter concerning the bark preventing catching cold Remarks upon its effects upon the blood Hewson Cold (Natural philosophy). Account of the experimental history of cold Boyle. A further account of Mr. Boyle's experimental history of cold Oldenburg. Promiscuous inquiries chiefly about cold; with answers to some of them by Hevelius. Tables of the barometrical altitudes at Zurich in Switzerland, in the year 1708, by Scheuchzer; and at Upminster in England, by Derham; as also the rain at Pifa in Italy, in 1707 and 1708, by Tilli; and at Zurich in 1708; and at Upminster in all that time; with remarks on the same tables; as also on the winds, heats and colds, and divers other matters occurring in those three different parts of Europe Derham. A contrivance to avoid the irregularities in a clock's motion, occasioned by the action of heat and cold upon the rod of a pendulum Graham. An observation of the magnetic needle being so affected by great cold, that it could not traverse Middleton. The effects of cold; together with observations of the longitude, latitude, and declination of the magnetic needle at Prince of Wales's Fort, upon Churchill River in Hudson's Bay, North America Middleton. A letter concerning a very cold day, and another concerning a very hot day, in June and July 1749 Miles. A letter concerning the difference of the degrees of cold, marked by a thermometer kept within doors, or without in the open air Miles. Two methods by which the irregularity of the motion of a clock, arising from the influence of heat and cold upon the rod of the pendulum, may be prevented Ellicott. Letter concerning the inventor of the contrivance in the pendulum of a clock, to prevent the irregularities of its motion by heat and cold Short. Observations on the late severe and cold weather Arderon. An account of artificial cold produced at Petersburg Himself. State of the cold at Berlin in the winter of 1762-3 — Pallas Account of the degree of cold observed in Bedfordshire, Nov. 22, 1763 — Howard Some account of the late cold weather, Jan. and Feb. 1767, at London — W. Watson At Plymouth — Anon. A note concerning the cold of 1740 and 1768 — Browne Observations on the same subject — Short Some remarks on the effects of cold in February 1771 — Richard Watson An account of the remarkable cold observed at Glasgow in January 1768 — Wilson Observations on the intense cold in the months of Jan. 1767 and 1768, and Nov. 1770, at Franeker — Van Swinden An account of a most extraordinary degree of cold at Glasgow in January 1780; together with some new experiments and observations on the comparative temperature of hoar-frost and the air near to it, made at Glasgow — Wilson See Heat and Thermometer. Colic. Letter concerning an unusual colic — Davies An account of an extraordinary effect of the colic — St. André An account of an extraordinary colic — Huxham Collision. A remark upon the new opinion relating to the forces of moving bodies, in the case of the collision of non-elastic bodies — Bamei Cologne. Remarks on the stones in the county of Naflau, and the territories of Treves and Cologne, resembling those of the Giant's Causeway in Ireland — Trembley Colon. An account of part of the colon hanging out of a wound for 14 years — Vater Colonies. Observations on the Roman colonies and stations in Cheshire and Lancashire — Percival Colour. An essay upon the causes of the different colours of people in different climates — Mitchell Colours (Chemistry). An experiment of a way of preparing a liquor that shall sink into and colour the whole body of marble, causing a picture drawn on a surface to appear also in the inner parts of the stone — Kircher and others An account of the use of the grain kermes for colouration — Verny A way of colouring fruit - Tonge A way of colouring leaves - Tonge Some observations touching colours, in order to the increase of dies, and the fixation of colours - Lister An account of an insect feeding upon hentane; the horrid smell of which is in that creature so qualified, as to become in some measure aromatic; together with the colour yeilded by the eggs of the same - Lister An account of an extraordinary tincture given to a stone - Reisell A Latin and English catalogue of simple and mixed colours, with a specimen of each colour fixed to its proper name - Waller An experiment in which a surprising change of colour, from a pale transparent or clear liquor, to a very blue ceruleous one, and that in an instant, by the admission of air only: was applied to illustrate some changes of colour, and other effects on the blood of respiring animals - Sare Two letters giving an account of a red colour produced by the mixture of a sulphureous spirit with a volatile alcali - Gibbons To give iron the colour and tincture of copper - Southwell A way to make two clear spirituous inflammable liquors, which differ very little in taste and smell; and being mixed together, do give a fine carnation colour, without either sensible fermentation or alteration - Geoffroy Method of colouring marbles - Anon. An account of two observations in gardening, upon the change of colour in grapes and jasmine - Cane An account of the bones of animals being changed to a red colour by aliment only - Betchin Observations and experiments with madder root, which has the faculty of tinging the bones of living animals of a red colour - Du Monceau Observations of the effects which the farina of peas of different colours have on each other - Henchman An account of a new die from the berries of a weed in South Carolina — Lindo Experiments and observations on the agreement between the specific gravities of the several metals and their colours, when united to glass, as well as those of their other proportions — Delaval An account of rings consisting of all the prismatic colours made by electrical explosions on the surfaces of pieces of metal — Priestley A letter on his new phosphorus receiving several colours, and only emitting the same Beccaria A letter giving some account of the roots used by the Indians in the neighbourhood of Hudson's Bay, to dye porcupine quills — Foster Experiments on dying black — Clegg Experiments on a new colouring substance from the island of Amsterdam, in the South Seas — Woulfe Colour (Natural philosophy). Letter containing his new theory of light and colours — Newton Extracts of several letters concerning the appearance of several arches of colours contiguous to the inner edge of the common rainbow at Petworth — Langwith Another letter, with some reflections on the same subject — Pemberton An account of persons who could not distinguish colours — Huddart See Light. Undertakings concerning the variation of the magnetical compass, and the inclination of the inclinatory needle, as the result and conclusion of 38 years magnetical study - Bond A theory of the variation of the magnetical compass - Halley Letter concerning a new sort of a magnetical compass; with several curious magnetical experiments - De la Hire The variation of the compass, or magneticall needle, needle, in the Atlantick and Ethiopick Oceans, 1766 Some remarks on the variations of the magnetical compass, published in the Memoirs of the Academy of Sciences, with regard to the general chart of those variations made by E. Halley; as also concerning the longitude of the Magellan Straights. The variation of the magnetical compass observed in a passage from Cape St. Lucar, in California, to the Isle of Guan, or Guana, one of the Ladrones; with some remarks thereon. A new and exact table, collected from several observations taken in four voyages to Hudson's Bay from London: shewing the variation of the magnetical needle, or sea compass, in the pathway to the said bay, according to the several longitudes and latitudes, from 1721 to 1725. A new and exact table collected from several observations taken from the year 1721 to 1729, in nine voyages to Hudson's Bay, in North America: shewing the variation of the compass, according to the latitudes and longitudes, accounting the longitude from the meridian of London. The use of a new azimuth-compass for finding the variation of the compasses, or magnetic needle, at sea, with greater ease and exactness than by any yet contrived for that purpose. A letter shewing, that the electricity of glass disturbs the mariner's compass, and also nice balances. On the effects of lightening in destroying the polarity of the mariner's compass; to which are subjoined, some remarks by Gowin Knight. A description of a mariner's compass contrived by Gowin Knight. An account of some improvements of the mariner's compass, in order to render the card and needle proposed by Dr. Knight of general use. The variation of the compass; containing 1719 observations to, in, and from, the East Indies. Guinea, West Indies, and Mediterranean, with the latitudes and longitudes at the time of observations — Douglas Tract of his majesty's armed brig Lion, from England to Davis's Streights and Labrador; with observations for determining the longitudes by sun and moon, and errors of common reckoning: also the variation of the compass and dip of the needle, as observed during the said voyage in 1776 — Pickersgill See Needle. An account of the appearance of lightening on a conductor, fixed from the summit of the main-mast of a ship down to the water — Winn An account of the effects of lightening on a house which was furnished with a pointed conductor, at Tenterden in Kent; to which are added, some remarks by Mr. Henley Haffenden New experiments and observations on the nature and use of conductors — Wilson Experiments in electricity; being an attempt to shew the advantage of elevated conductors New experiments upon the Leyden phial, respecting the termination of conductors See Lightening. Cones. An investigation of a general theorem for finding the length of any arc of any conic hyperbola by means of two elliptic arcs, with some other new and useful theorems deduced therefrom Conformation. A remarkable conformation or latus naturae in a child Two observations of a diseased conformation in bodies Diseased conformations found in bodies Congelation. Account of a sudden congelation Congelation. See Frost. Conglaciation. See Frost. Conic Sections. Some simple properties of conic sections, deduced from the nature of focus's, &c. Instances, hints, and applications, relating to a main point, solicited in the preface to this fourth volume; concerning the use may be made of vaults, deep wells, and cold conservatories, to find out the cause, or to promote promote the generation of salt, minerals, metals, crystal; gems, stones of divers kinds; and helps to conserve long, or to have nutrification, fertility of any kind of land, &c. **Constantinople.** Historical observations relating to Constantinople — A continuation of the historical observations relating to Constantinople — Journal of a voyage from London to Constantinople — See Population. **Contagion.** A discourse of the usefulness of inoculation of the horned cattle, to prevent the contagious distemper among them **Constitutions.** Some observations of odd constitutions of bodies **Contraction.** A cure of muscular contraction by electricity **Contrayerva.** An account of the contrayerva **Contusion.** Account of a rupture of the ilium from an internal contusion, unattended with any external wound **Convulsions.** The history of periodical convulsions — The history of a convulsive disease returning every eight years — An account of an unusual medicinal case of an hemorrhage of bloody tears in convulsion fits — Of the extraordinary effects of musk in convulsive disorders — Case of a boy troubled with convulsive fits cured by the discharge of worms — An account of some extraordinary effects arising from convulsions **Cookery.** An account of the Moorish way of dressing their meat (with some remarks) in West Barbary, from Cape Spartel to Cape de Geer **Copernicus.** An account of a portrait of Copernicus, presented to the Royal Society by Dr. Wolf of Dantziek **Copper.** Account of the copper-mine at Herrn Ground in Hungary A relation of persons killed with subterraneous damps Moray Letter concerning the damps in the mines of Hungary, and their effects Browne Extract of a letter containing some observations about damps Lister A letter containing a farther account of damp in mines — Jeffery Observations on a subterranean fire in a coal mine near Newcastle — Hodgson A relation of some strange phenomena, accompanied with mischievous effects in a colliery-work in Flintshire — Molyneux An account of the burning of several hay-ricks by a fiery exhalation or damp; and of the infectious quality of the grass of several grounds — Floyd Farther account of the fiery exhalation in Merionethshire — Llwyd An attempt made to shew how damps or foul air may be drawn out of any sort of mines, &c., by an engine — Desaguliers A brief account of some of the effects and properties of damps, from observations of the effects of opening an old well at Boston in New England, July 19, 1729 — Greenwood An account of the damp air in a coal-pit of Sir James Lowther, Bart., sunk within 20 yards of the sea — Lowther An experiment to shew that some damps in mines may be occasioned only by the burning of candles under ground; without the addition of any noxious vapour, even when the bottom of the pit has a communication with the outward air, unless the outward air be forcibly driven in at the said communication or pipe — Desaguliers An observation of an extraordinary damp in a well in the Isle of Wight — Cooke See Flame. Dantzig. A relation of an inland sea near Dantzig, yielding at a certain season of the year a green substance, which causeth certain death — Kirkby Darien. Part of a journal kept from Scotland to New Caledonia in Darien, with a short account of that country — Wallace Darkness. An account of a remarkable darkness at Detroit in America, Oct. 19, 1762 — Stirling Date. An account of an ancient mantle-tree in Northamptonshire, on which the date of it (for the year 1133) is expressed by the nume- ral figures, which shews the great antiquity of those figures in England Extract of a letter concerning an antient date found at Widge Hall in Hertfordshire Remarks on the above date Further account of it Remarks upon an antient date, over a gateway near the cathedral at Worcester An account of an antient date in Arabian figures, upon the north front of the parish church of Rumsey in Hampshire A brief inquiry into the reading of two dates in Arabian figures cut upon stones, which were found in Ireland A description of an antient date in Arabian figures at Walling, near Aldermanston, Berkshire Date-Stones. An extract of a letter containing microscopical observations on date stones Davenport (Ann). The case of Ann Davenport Davis's Quadrant. A description of a water-level to be fixed to Davis's quadrant, whereby an observation may be taken at sea in thick and hazy weather without seeing the horizon Davis's Straights. Instance to Mr. Hook, for communicating a contrivance of making, with a glass of a sphere of 20 or 40 foot diameter, a telescope drawing several hundred feet: and his offer of recompensing that secret with another, teaching to measure with a telescope the distances of objects upon the earth Auzout Of the correspondence to be procured for the finding out the true distance of the sun and moon from the earth by the parallax, observed under or near the same meridian Oldenburg A true copy of a paper found in the hand-writing of Sir Isaac Newton among the papers of Dr. Halley, describing an instrument for observing the moon's distance from the fixed stars at sea Some experiments in order to discover the height to which rockets may be made to ascend, and to what distance their light may be seen Ellicott A letter containing the results of observations of the distance of the moon from the sun and fixed stars, made in a voyage from England to the island of St. Helena, in order to determine the longitude of the ship from time to time; together with the whole process of computation used on this occasion Maskelyne Of the moon's distance and parallax Murdock Concise rules for computing the effects of refraction and parallax, in varying the apparent distance of the moon from the sun or a star: also an easy rule of approximation for computing the distance of the moon from a star; the longitudes and latitudes of both being given, with demonstrations of the same Maskelyne A method by which a glass of a small plano-convex sphere, may be made to refract the ray of light to a focus of a far greater distance than is usual — Hook Distempers. An anatomical account of some remarkable things found on the dissection of a woman, who died of a dropsy, after the paracentesis was performed; with a small reflection on the causes of the dropsy Preston A relation of a strange symptom attending a hydrops pectoris, and the reason of it, as it appeared on the dissection of the body Doudy An observation concerning a very odd kind of dropsy, or swelling in one of the ovaries of a woman Sloane An account of a dropsical body dissected by Lagage XXIV 1977 V 291 An account of an hydrops ovarii, with a new and exact figure of the glandulae renales, and of the uterus in a puerpera Douglas XXV 2317 — 294 A relation of an hydropical case, in which the gall-bladder was distended to an unusual degree Tonge XXVII 426 — 292 An account of a dropsy in the left ovary of a woman, aged 58, cured by a large incision made in the side of the abdomen Houltoun XXXIII 8 VII 541 A remarkable case of a gentlewoman who died of an hydrops ovarii in the 33rd year of her age, after having been tapped 57 times Belchier XXXVII 279 — 544 The case of Mr. Cox, surgeon, of Peterborough, who fell into a pestilential fever, upon tapping a corpse lately dead of an hydropsy Cox XLI 168 IX 212 The case of an extraordinary dropsy Short XLII 223 — 150 An improvement on the practice of tapping, whereby that operation, instead of a relief for symptoms, becomes an absolute cure for an ascites; exemplified in the case of Jane Roman Warrick XLIII 12 XI 1030 A method of conveying liquors into the abdomen during the operation of tapping Hales — 20 Further accounts of the success of injecting medicated liquors into the abdomen, in the case of an ascites Warren — 47 Account of an uncommon dropsy from the want of a kidney; and a large saccus that contained the water Glafis XLIV 337 — 1027 An account of some cases of dropsies cured by sweet oil Oliver XLIX 46 An account of a successful operation for the hydrops pectoris Moreland LVI 302 An account of an extraordinary dropsical case Latham LXIX 54 Dropsy. Observations on the annual evaporation at Liverpool, in Lancashire, and on evaporation, considered as a test of the moisture or dryness of the atmosphere. DUBLIN. An account of the houes and hearths in Dublin, in 1695 and 1696. DUCKS. Observations made about the lasting of ducks, included in the exhausted receiver. DUCKWEED. A new discovery of the communication of the ductus thoracicus with the emulgent vein. An account of two glands, and their excretory ducts, lately discovered in human bodies. Advertisements occasioned by the remarks printed in No. XIV. upon frosts in some parts of Scotland, differing in their anniversary reasons and force from our ordinary frosts in England: of black winds and tempests, of the warm and fertilizing temperature and streams of the earth, stones, rocks, springs, waters (some in some places more than others in other places), of petrifying and metallizing waters; with some hints for the horticulture of Scotland Beal EARTH. Speculations of the changes likely to be discovered in the earth and moon by their respective inhabitants Auzout — Instance to Mr. Hook for communicating a contrivance of making, with a glass of a sphere of 20 or 40 feet diameter, a telescope drawing several hundred feet; and his offer of recompensing that secret with another, teaching to measure with a telescope the distances of objects from the earth Auzout — Of the correspondence to be procured for the finding out the true distance of the sun and moon from the earth, by the parallax observed under or near the same meridian Oldenburg EAR An account of a controversy between Stephano de Angelis of Padua and J. A narrative of some observations made upon several voyages, to find a way for sailing about the North to the East Indies, and for returning the same way from hence hither; together with instructions given by the Dutch East India Company for the discovery of Jesso, near Japan: to which is added, a relation of sailing through the Northern America to the East Indies Van Nierop Part of a letter from Fort St. George in the East Indies, giving an account of the long worm, which is troublesome to the inhabitants of those parts Lister Account of some animals sent from the East Indies, with remarks by J. Remarks upon a petrified echinus of a singular singular kind, found on Bunnan's Land, in the parish of Bovingdon in Hertfordshire, which is a clay, and supposed to have been brought with the chalk dug out of a pit in the field. Parfons An account of a remarkable echinus Brander Eclipses. A method for observing the eclipses of the moon free from the common inconveniencies. See Sun, Moon. Ecliptic. Some more accurate observations about Jupiter's transits near fixed stars; useful for determining the inclination of that planet to the ecliptique Flamstead An account shewing, that the latitude of Nurenburg has continued without sensible alteration for 200 years last past; as likewise the obliquity of the ecliptick, by comparing them with what was observed by B. Walther in 1487 Wuritz Ibaur A proposal to make the poles of a globe of the heavens move in a circle round the poles of the ecliptic Latham A contrivance to make the poles of the diurnal motion, in a celestial globe, pass round the poles of the ecliptic Senex A treatise on the precession of the equinoxes, and in general on the motion of the nodes, and the alteration of the inclination of the orbit of a planet to the ecliptic. An enquiry into the quantity and direction of the proper motion of Arcturus; with some remarks on the diminution of the obliquity of the ecliptic. Eden. An account of a remarkable decrease of the river Eden in Cumberland Dec. 28, 1762. Edinburgh. A comparison of the heat of London and Edinburgh. Edwards. An account of what appeared most remarkable on opening the body of Anne Edwards, who died Jan. 5, 1729-30, having a large umbilical rupture. Eels. Method of taking eels in frosty weather. An abstract of a letter concerning the scales of eels. Microscopical observations on eels, mites, the seeds of figs, strawberries, &c. Of the manner of generation of eels. An account of a very large eel lately caught at Malden in Essex; with some considerations about the generation of eels. Manner of observing the circulation of blood in an eel. Observations on the mouths of the eels in vinegar, and also a strange aquatic animal. A letter concerning the minute cells in paste being viviparous. Abstract of a letter concerning the peculiar affec't of eels. Effervescence. A memoir on the lacryma batavice, or glass drops, the tempering of steel, and effervescence, accounted for by the same principle. The strange effects of some effervescent mixtures. Effluvia. Several experiments shewing the strange effects of the effluvia of glass, producible on the motion and attrition of it.
