An explanation of the cuts of two porphyry pillars in Egypt - Huntington Extract of a letter concerning a supposed connection between the hieroglyphical writing of ancient Egypt, and the characteristic writing which is in use at this day among the Chinese - Morton ELASTICITY. A remark upon the new opinion relating to the forces of moving bodies, in the case of the collision of non-elastic bodies - Eams An experiment to prove that water, when agitated by fire, is infinitely more elastic than air in the same circumstances - Clayton A narrative of a new invention of expanding fluids, by their being conveyed into certain ignited vessels, where they are immediately rarified into an elastic impelling force, sufficient to give motion to hydraulopneumatical and other engines, for raising water, and other uses, &c. An attempt to explain some of the principal phenomena of electricity by means of an elastic fluid Continuation of an experimental enquiry concerning the nature of the mineral elastic spirit or air contained in the Pouhon water, and other acidulæ Experiments for discovering the various elasticity of the air in different parts of Switzerland Some thoughts and conjectures concerning the cause of elasticity See Air. Electrical experiments to explain how far the phenomena of the electrophorus may be accounted for by Dr. Franklin's theory of positive and negative electricity - Ingenhouz Observations and experiments tending to confirm Dr. Ingenhouz's theory of electropho- rus; and to shew the impermeability of glass to electric fluid. **Elephant.** An account of the skeleton of an elephant lately dug up at Tonna — Tentzelius — An account of the taking and training of elephants in Zeylan — Strachan — A full and exact description of all the bones of an elephant, with their several dimensions. To which are premised, an historical account of the natural endowments and several wonderful performances of elephants, with the manner of taking and training them; an anatomical account of its parts, &c. — Blair A continuation — Blair — Some remarks upon the disposition of the parts; and microscopical observations upon the contexture of the skin of elephants — Leeuwenhoek — A description of the organ of hearing in the elephant, with the figures and situation of the osificles, labyrinth and cochlea, in the ear of that animal — Blair — An account of elephants teeth and bones found under ground, Part I. — Sloane Part II. — Sloane — Observations, and a description of some mammoth's bones dug up in Siberia, proving them to have belonged to elephants — Breyn — Letter concerning an extraordinary large fossil tooth of an elephant — Baker — An account of several bones of an elephant found at Leydown in the Isle of Sheppey — Jacob — Observations on the bones commonly supposed to be elephants bones, which have been found near the river Ohio in America — William Hunter — A dissertation on the bones and teeth of elephants, and other beasts, found in North America, and other northern regions, by which it appears they are the bones of indigenous beasts — Rapse **Ellicott.** Observations for proving the going of Mr. Ellicott's clock at St. Helena — Mason — See Clock. **Ellipse.** A direct and geometrical method by which the aphelia, eccentricities, and proportions of the orbs of the primary planets may be determined, without supposing the equality of the angle of motion. motion at the other focus of the planet's ellipsis Halley Investigation to prove, that the figure of the earth approaches nearly to an ellipsis, according to the laws of attraction in an inverse ratio of the square of the distances Clairaut Elliptic. An investigation of a general theorem for finding the length of any arc of any conic hyperbola by means of two elliptic arcs; with some other new and useful theorems deduced therefrom Landen Elms. An extract of a letter concerning the propagation of elms by seed Buckley Embalming. An abstract of Necromantia; or the art of embalming Greenhill Embryo. Experiments concerning the encaustic painting of the ancients Colebrooke A letter concerning the success of the former experiments Colebrooke See Painting. The greatest effect of engines with uniformly accelerated motions considered A method of lessening the quantity of friction in engines Short and easy methods for finding the quantity and weight of water contained in a full pipe of any given height and diameter of bore; and consequently, to find what degree of power would would be required to work a common pump, or any other hydraulic engine, when the diameter of the pump bore, and the height to which the water is to be raised therein are given Ferguson. Some Hortulan communications about the curious engrafting of oranges and lemons, or citrons, upon one another's trees; and of one individual fruit, half orange and half lemon, growing on such trees, &c. De Moivre Extract of a letter containing a commodious disposition of equations so exhibiting the relations of goniometrical lines — Jones The application of Dr. Saunderson's theorem for solving unlimited equations to a curious question in chronology — Horsfall Directions for making a machine for finding the roots of equations universally; with the manner of using it — Rowning A method of extending Cardan's rule for resolving one case of a cubic equation $x^3 - qx = r$ to the other case of the same equation, which it is not naturally fitted to solve, and which is therefore called the irreducible case — Maiores Appendix — Maiores A conjecture concerning the method by which Cardan's rules for resolving the cubic equation $x^3 + qx = r$ in all cases (or in all magnitudes of the known quantities $q$ and $r$) and the cubic equation $x^3 - qx = r$ in the first case of it (or when $r$ is greater than $\frac{27}{3\sqrt{3}}$, or $\frac{rr}{4}$ is greater than $\frac{q^2}{27}$) were probably discovered by Scipio Ferreus of Bononia, or whoever else was the first inventor of them — Maiores Of cubic equations and infinite series — Hutton Equation of Time. Some observations and experiments made, and in a letter communicated to the publisher for the Royal Society, by the learned and inquisitive Martin Lister An account of some experiments made before the Royal Society by F. Slare, with short applications of them to physical matters. 1. A parallel between lightening and a phosphorus. 2. By mixing two liquors actually cold, to produce such sparkling and fiery bodies as are not only visible in the dark, but at noon day in the enlightened air. 3. By the addition of an oil to the foregoing mixture to produce a flame. 4. A refutation of Borrichius's experiment that pretends to accension 5. A new experiment with ebullition and incalcescence. 6. Of cold produced without ebullition; giving some account of hysterical paroxysms. 7. Of cold produced by a very great ebullition, wherein the cold and hot fits of an ague are resembled by a mixture of liquors. A miscellaneous catalogue of mean, vulgar, cheap and simple experiments — Petty Explosion. An account of what happened to a child who swallowed two copper farthings Baynard Fascination. Conjectures on the charming or fascinating power attributed to the rattle-snake; grounded on credible accounts, experiments, and observations Sloan Fat. Remarks on the very different accounts that have been given of the fecundity of fish, with fresh observations on that subject Harmer Feet. The description and use of the pores in the skin of the hands and feet Grew Case of Nicholas Reeks, who was born with his feet turned inwards, which came to rights after being some time used to sit cross-legged Hütter Females. An account of what has been of late observed of eggs to be found in all sorts of females Kerkringius Fermat (M. De). Character of M. de Fermat Oldenburg Fermentation. Observations on these three chemical operations, digestion, fermentation, and triture, or grinding (hitherto, in the author's opinion, not sufficiently regarded), by which many things of admirable use may be performed Langelot A way to make two clear spirituous inflammable liquors, which differ very little in taste and smell; and being mixed together, do give a fine carnation colour, without either sensible fermentation or alteration Geoffroy Observations upon the dissolutions and fermentations which we may call cold, because they are accompanied with a coolness of the liquors into which they pass Geoffroy FERN. A letter concerning the seed of fern FERREUS SCIPIO. See Equation. FERTILITY. Instances, hints, and regulations relating to a main point, solicited in the preface to this fourth volume, concerning the use to be made of vaults, deep wells, and cold conservatories, to find out the cause or to promote the generation of salt, minerals, metals, crystals, gems, stones of divers kinds; and helps to conserve long or to hasten putrefaction, fertility of any kind of land, &c. FEVER. Observations on dissection, and the motion of the blood in a fever — A discourse of the operation of a blister when it cures a fever — A letter concerning the whiteness on the tongue in fevers — A relation of a deaf and dumb person who recovered his hearing and speech after a violent fever; with some other medical and chirurgical observations — A letter containing his observations upon the white matter on the tongues of feverish persons — Of the use of cold water in fevers — A letter relating to the cure of intermitting fevers at Tunis — The case of Mr. Cox, surgeon, of Peterborough, who fell into a pestilential fever upon tapping a corpse late dead of an hydropfy — An account of several persons seized with the gaol-fever working in Newgate, and of the manner in which the infection was communicated to one entire family — An account of those malignant fevers that raged at Rouen at the end of the year 1753, and the beginning of 1754 — Case of the efficacy of bark in the delirium of a fever — Letter on the good effects of the quassia roots in fevers at Antigua — Observations of a sick man surprizingly recovered from a fever — Case of a man seized with a fever from the effects of meal-dust FIBRES. A discourse concerning the spiral, instead of the supposed annular structure of the fibres of the intestines — Cole Extract of a letter concerning the fibres of the muscles — Leeuwenhoek Observations upon the membranes enclosing the fasciculi of fibres, into which a muscle is divided — Leeuwenhoek Observations on the muscular fibres of different animals — Leeuwenhoek An observation on the double fibres observable in the skeletons prepared from green leaves — Hollman Conjectures on the use of double fibres in some leaves, &c. — Hollman FIELDING. A brief narrative of the shot of Dr. Robert Fielding with a musket bullet, and its strange manner of coming out of his head, where it had laid near 30 years: written by himself — Fielding FIGURES. An account of an antient mantle-tree in Northamptonshire, on which the date of it (for the year 1133) is expressed by the numeral figures, which shews the great antiquity of those figures in England — Luffkin On the use of numeral figures in England, as old as 1090 — Wallis Letter concerning the use of the numeral figures in England in 1090 — Wallis Extract of a letter concerning an antient date found at Widge Hall in Hertfordshire — Cope Remarks on the above date — Ward Further accounts of it — Gulston Some considerations on the antiquity and use of the Indian characters or figures — Cope Remarks upon an antient date over a gateway, near the cathedral at Worcester — Ward An account of an antient date in Arabian figures, upon the north front of the parish church of Rumsey in Hampshire — Barlow A brief inquiry into the reading of two dates in Arabian figures cut upon stones, which were found in Ireland — Ward A description of an antient date in Arabian figures at Walling, near Aldermaryton, Berkshire — Ward Concerning the various figures of the salts contained in several substances — Leeuwenhoek Transf. (Specific). An invention for estimating the weight of water in water with ordinary balances and weights Of the weight of a cubic foot of divers grains A further list of specific gravities of bodies A discourse on this problem; why bodies, dissolved in menstrua specifically lighter than themselves, swim therein Some reflections on the foregoing paper Observations on the comparative, intensive or specific gravities of various bodies An account of an experiment touching the proportion of the weight of air to the weight of a like bulk of water, without knowing the quantity of either An experiment touching the weighing of bodies of the same species, but of very unequal surfaces faces in common water, being of an equal weight in common air Of several metallic cubes, in comparison with their like bulks of water A description of the several strata of earth, stone, coal, &c. found in a coal-pit at the west end of Dudley, Staffordshire. To which is added, a table of the specific gravity of each stratum A caution to be used in examining the specific gravity of solids by weighing them in water The specific gravities of certain matters observed at different times for various purposes A letter concerning the specific gravity of diamonds Tables of specific gravities; extracted from various authors; with some observations upon the same An essay towards ascertaining the specific gravity of living men Experiments and observations on the agreement between the specific gravities of the several metals and their colours when united to glass, as well as those of their other proportions A course of experiments to ascertain the respective weights and buoyancy of salt water and fresh water, and for determining the exact weight of human and other bodies in fluids Greatrix. A proposition of general use in the art of gunnery; shewing the rule of laying a mortar to pass, in order to strike any object above or below the horizon The description of a new quadrant for taking an altitude without an horizon, either at sea or land A spirit-level to be fixed to a quadrant for taking a meridional altitude at sea when the horizon is not visible An attempt to explain the phenomenon of the horizontal moon, appearing bigger than when elevated many degrees about the horizon; supported by an experiment An explication of the experiment Some thoughts on the sun and moon when near the horizon, appearing larger than when in the zenith A description of a water-level to be fixed to Davis's quadrant, whereby an observation may be taken at sea in thick and hazy weather, without seeing the horizon The description and use of an apparatus added as an improvement to Davis's quadrant, consisting of a mercurial level for taking the co-altitude of sun or star at sea, without the usual assistance of the sensible horizon which frequently is obscured See Moon and Sun. A discourse concerning the large horns frequently found under ground in Ireland; concluding from them, that the great American deer, called a moose, was formerly common in that island Molyneux XIX 489 III 544 An account of horns found under ground in Ireland Kelly XXXIV 122 VI 2 224 An account of a pair of very extraordinary large horns found in Wapping some years since; with a probable account whence they came, and to what animal they belonged Sloane — 222 VII 441 A letter serving to accompany the pictures of an extraordinary fossil skull of an ox with the cores of the horns Klein XXXVII 427 IV 4-101 Of the horn of a large deer found in the heart of an oak Clark XLI 235 VIII 847 An account of two extraordinary deers horns found under ground in different parts of Yorkshire Knowlton XLIV 124 X 601 Horrox. The case of Mary Howell, who had a needle run into her arm and came out at her breast Hudson's Bay. Observations on the state of the air, winds, weather, &c. at the Prince of Wales's Fort on the north-west coast of Hudson's Bay, in 1768 and 1769 An account of birds sent from Hudson's Bay; with observations relative to their natural history; and Latin descriptions of some of the most uncommon Hummer. An account of the sunk island in Hummer, some years since recovered from the sea Humming Bird. Divers rural and economical enquiries recommended to observation and trial Some agricltive observations and advertisements Continuation of the hortulan and rural advertisements HYADES. An advertisement to astronomers, of the advantage that may accrue from the observation of the moon's frequent appulses to the hyades, during the three next ensuing years. HYDATIDES. Lumbricus hydropicus, or an essay to prove, that hydatides, often met with in morbid animal bodies, are a species of worms, or imperfect animals A relation of a person who voided many hydatides in her urine A letter concerning hydatides voided by stool Of hydatides inclosed with a stony crust in the kidney of a sheep An observation of a tumour on the neck full of hydatides, cured by An account of a great quantity of hydatides found in the abdomen An observation of hydatides voided per vaginam Two medico-chirurgical observations on the hydatides, and consequences of an incomplete hernia, and on the functions of the intestines exposed to sight Hydraulics. Remarks upon some experiments in hydraulics, which seem to prove, that the forces of equal moving bodies are as the squares of their velocities Short and easy methods for finding the quantity and weight of water contained in a full pipe of any given height and diameter of bore; and, consequently, to find what degree of power would be required to work a common pump, or any other hydraulic engine, when the diameter of the pump-bore, and the height to which the water is to be raised therein, are given Hydraulic Engine. A description of an hydraulic engine Hydraulopneumatics. A narrative of a new invention of expanding fluids by their being conveyed into certain ignited vessels, where they are immediately rarified into an elastic impelling force sufficient to give motion to hydau- Hydrocephalus. A new trocart for the puncture in the hydrocephalus and for other evacuations, which are necessary to be made at different times. Hydro-enterocele. An account of an hydro-enterocele, appearing like a hydro-farcocele, and ending in the death of the patient, in which the intestines had passed from the hernial sac into that of the hydrocele, by which the strangulation was formed. Hydrologia. Some reflections made on the enlarged account of Dr. Witties answer to hydrologia chymica, chiefly concerning the cause of the sudden loss of the virtues of mineral waters. Hydrometer. Account of a new kind of hydrometer. Hydrophobia. Relation of a man bitten with a mad dog, and dying of the disease called hydrophobia. A remarkable account of an hydrophobia. An account of three cases of the hydrophobia. An account of the case of a supposed hydrophobia. Hydro-sarcocele. An account of an hydro-enterocele appearing like a hydro-farcocele, and ending in the death of the patient; in which the intestine had passed from the hernial sac into that of the hydrocele, by which the strangulation was formed. Hydrops ovarii. An account of an hydrops ovarii, with a new and exact figure of the glandulae renales, and of the uterus in a puerpera. A remarkable case of a gentlewoman who died of a hydrops ovarii in the 33rd year of her age, after having been tapped fifty-seven times. Hydrostatic. A description of a new essay-instrument, together with the hydrostatical principles; it is founded on Extract of a letter relating to the essay-instrument. HYGROMETER. See Hygrometer. HYOSCYAMUS ALBUS. The effects of the hyoscyamus albus - Stedman HYPERBOLA. The squaring of the hyperbola by an infinite series of rational numbers; together with its demonstration - Brouncker — Answer to the animadversions of Mr. Hugenius upon Dr. Gregory's book, De vera circuli & hyperbolæ quadratura, as published in the journal Des Scavans - Gregory — Some considerations upon M. Hugens's letter, printed in vindication of his examen of the book entituled, Vera circuli & hyperbolæ quadratura - Gregory — The generation of an hyperbolical cylindroid demonstrated; and the application thereof, for grinding hyperbolical glasses, hinted at - Wren — A description of Dr. Chr. Wren's engine, designed for grinding hyperbolical glasses, as it was in a manner promised, vol. III. p. 962 - Wren — On the center of gravity of hyperbolas - Wallis — A compendious and facile method for constructing the logarithms, exemplified and demonstrated from the nature of numbers, without any regard to the hyperbola; with a speedy method for finding the number from the logarithm given - Halley The construction and properties of a new quadratrix to the hyperbola — Perks XXV 2253 IV 37 The general quadrature of trinomial hyperbolic curves; delivered in two theorems Klingerstein XXXVII 45 VI 82 An investigation of a general theorem for finding the length of any arc of any conic hyperbola by means of two elliptic arcs; with some other new and useful theorems deduced therefrom — Landen LXV 283 Hypnum Terrestre. D. during his voyage to, and residence in, the empire of Japan. JAVA-MAJOR. Answer to some of the queries which were recommended by Sir R. Moray to Sir P. Vernatti, president at Java Major. JAUNDICE. Letter concerning a contumacious jaundice, accompanied with a very odd case in vision. A letter concerning the jaundice, occasioned by a stone obstructing the ductus communis biliares, which was afterwards voided by stool. Part of a letter concerning a child born with the jaundice upon it, received from its father; and of the mother taking the same distemper from her husband the next time of being with child. Jaw. Observations upon the effects of electricity applied to a tetanus, or muscular rigidity of four months continuance. Cafe of a locked jaw. Account of a locked jaw and paralysis, cured by electricity. ICE. A way of preserving ice and snow by chaff. Some experiments shewing the difference of ice made without air, from that which is produced with air. Some experiments about freezing, and the difference between common fresh water ice and that of the sea water: also a probable conjecture about the original of the nitre of Egypt. New experiments upon ice. An examination of sea water frozen and melted again, to try what quantity of salt is contained in such ice; made in Hudson's Straights by Capt. Christopher Middleton, at the request of C. Mortimer. The process of making ice in the East Indies. Experiments on water obtained from the melted ice of sea water, to ascertain whether it be fresh or not, &c. See Frost. ICELAND. Account of sundry experiments made upon a crystal-like body sent from Iceland. An answer to some philosophical inquiries concerning that country **Ichneumon Worms.** Some considerable observations upon that kind of wasps called Vespae Ichneumones, especially their several ways of breeding; and among them that odd way of laying their eggs in the bodies of caterpillars, &c. A letter enlarging his observations about Ichneumon worms **Iconantidiptic Telescope.** An account of an Iconantidiptic telescope **Icy Mountain.** Letter concerning the icy or crystalline mountains of Helvetia, called the Gletscher A further description and representation of the icy mountain, called the Gletscher, in the canton of Berne in Helvetia Part of a letter concerning the icy mountains in Switzerland **Idiot.** An account of an idiot at Ostend **Jelly.** Some observations concerning the virtue of the jelly of black currants in curing inflammations in the throat **Jenkins (Henry).** Account of one Henry Jenkins who attained the age of 169 years; with remarks **Jessamine.** An account of two observations in gardening, upon the change of colour in grapes and jessamine **Jesso.** A narrative of some observations made upon several voyages, to find a way for sailing about the North to the East Indies, and for returning the same way from thence hither; together with instructions given by the Dutch East India Company for the discovery of Jesso near Japan. Remarks on Hadley's quadrant, tending principally to remove the difficulties which have hitherto attended the use of the back observation, and to obviate the errors that might arise from a want of parallelism in the two surfaces of the index glass INDICTIONS. A method for finding the numbers of the Julian period for any year assigned, the number of the cycle of the sun, the cycle of the moon, and of the indictions for the same year being given; together with a demonstration of that method INDIES. Some observations concerning a possible passage to the East Indies, by the Northern America, westward — Some observations sent from the East Indies, in answer to some queries sent thither — An account of some Indian plants, &c. with their names, descriptions, and virtues — Letter concerning some Indian manuscripts lately sent to the university of Oxford — A letter containing some observations on the mechanic arts of the Indians — A letter containing some observations on the physic of the Indians — An account of the Indian hot-houses — An abstract of a letter concerning experiments made on the Indian magnetick sand — Some considerations on the antiquity and use of the Indian characters or figures — Account of an antidote to the Indian poison in the West Indies — An account of the male and female cochineal insect that breed on the cactus opuntia, or Indian fig, in South Carolina or Georgia — An account of an extraordinary disease among the Indians in the islands of Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard in New England — Some attempts to ascertain the utmost extent of the knowledge of the antients in the East Indies — A description and figure of the nyctanthes elongata, a new Indian plant A letter giving some account of the roots used by the Indians in the neighbourhood of Hudson's Bay, to dye porcupine quills Extraits of some letters on the customs, manners and language of the northern Indians of America Indian Corn. An anatomical observation of four ureters in an infant Account of an infant musician Infection. An account of several persons seized with the gaol fever working in Newgate, and of the manner in which the infection was communicated to one entire family Infinite. The squaring of the hyperbola by an infinite series of rational numbers; together with its demonstration An account of the several species of infinite quantity, and of the proportion they bear one to the other A method of raising an infinite multinomial to any given power, or extracting any given root of the same A method of extracting the root of an infinite equation Analytical solution of certain infinitesimal equations Some theorems respecting the infinite divisibility of matter A solution of the 15th general problem propofered by D. De Moivre, in his treatise De Mensura Sortis Another general solution of the preceding problem, with the assistance of combinations or infinite series Of cubic equations and infinite series Inflammable Liquors. A way to make two clear spirituous inflammable liquors, which differ very little in taste and smell; and being mixed together, do give a fine carnation colour, without either sensible fermentation or alteration. Geoffroy INFLAMMATIONS. Some observations concerning the virtue of the jelly of black currants in curing inflammations in the throat. Baker An account of a brittle that was lodged in a gentleman's foot, and caused a violent inflammation. Arderon Case of a young lady who drank sea water for an inflammation and tumour in the upper lip. Lewington INFUSION INTO VEINS. Account of the success of some experiments of infusing medicines into human veins. Anon. INGUINAL RUPTURE. Of an inguinal rupture, with a pin in the appendix coeci, incrusted with stone. Amyan Injection. A confirmation of the experiments made by Sig. Fracassati in Italy, by injecting acid liquors into the blood. Boyle Anatomical inventions and observations, particularly the origin of the injection into veins. Clark An account of the dissection of a dog who had mercury injected into one of the jugulars. Pitt Further accounts of the success of injecting medicated liquors into the abdomen, in the case of an abscess. Warren INOCULATION. of a place at any given time of the day A true copy of a paper found in the hand-writing of Sir Isaac Newton, among the papers of Dr. Halley, describing an instrument for observing the moon's distance from the fixed stars at sea An explanation of a new instrument made for measuring small angles An account of the meteorological instruments used at the Royal Society's house Account of a new instrument for measuring small angles, called the prismatic micrometer An account of the apparatus applied to the equatorial instrument, for correcting the errors arising from the refraction in altitude An account of some new experiments in electricity, with the description and use of two new electrical instruments INSTRUMENTS (Musical) Account of a musical instrument brought from the isle of Amsterdam in the South Seas 1774, by captain Furneaux See Telescope, Microscope, Micrometer, &c. in their places INTEREST. Rules for correcting the usual methods of computing amounts and present values by compound as well as simple interest, and of stating interest accounts Investigations of twenty cases of compound interest INTERPOLATIONS. Problems concerning interpolations Intestines. Observations on part of the intestines of a dog successfully cut away — Shipton Account of a pain in the belly arising from the intestines being concreted into a cartilaginous substance — M. Japaritus Microscopical observations on the blood vessels, and membranes of the intestines — Leeuwenhoek Account of a rupture of the ilium from an external contusion, attended with no external wound — Wolfius Two medico-chirurgical observations on the hydratides, and consequences of an incomplete hernia and on the functions of the intestines exposed to sight — Le Cat An account of an iliac passion from a palsy in the large intestines — De Castro An account of a very remarkable case of a boy who, notwithstanding that a considerable part of his intestines were forced out by the fall of a cart upon him, and afterwards cut off, recovered, and continues well — Needham A remarkable case of cohesions of all the intestines in a man of about 34 years of age — Jenty An extraordinary cure of wounded intestines — Nourse See Particular intestines in their places. Inventions. A paper asserting some mathematical inventions to their true authors — Gregory Inundation. An account of an extraordinary inundation in the island of Mauritius — Diodati A letter giving an account of some inundations in Ireland, 1708 — Derham An account of a surprizing inundation in the valley of St. John's, near Keswick in Cumberland, Aug. 22, 1749 — Anon. Jointed Worm. Lumbricus latus, or a discourse of the jointed worm — Tyson Joints. Two singular cures of diseased knee-joints successfully treated; the first by topical applications, the second by operation — Warner Account of the case of the first joint of the thumb thumb torn off, with the flexor tendon in its whole extent torn out — Home IPECAUCANHA. Of the use of the root ipecacuanha for loosenesses; translated from a French paper, with notes, by — H. Sloane — A short account of the different kinds of ipecacuanha — Douglas — Medico-physical observations on ipecacuanha (Lat.) — Gmelin IRELAND. Of the bogs and loughs of Ireland King — A discourse concerning the large horns frequently found under ground in Ireland; concluding from them, that the great American deer, called a moose, was formerly common in that island — Molyneux — Several observations relating to the antiquities and natural history of Ireland, in travels through that kingdom — Lhuyd — Some further observations relating to the antiquities and natural history of Ireland Lhuyd — An account of horns found under ground in Ireland — King — Part of a letter concerning the remains of an antient temple in Ireland, and of a stone hatchet of the antient Irish — Bp. of Cork — See Figures, Population. IRIS. Observations on an evening, or rather nocturnal solar iris, June 5, 1757 — Edwards — See Rainbow. IRON. An account of two mineral substances found in some coal and iron mines in England — Jesop — An account of the iron works in the forest of Dean — Powle — Several observations of the respect of the needle to a piece of iron held perpendicular; made by a master of a ship crossing the equinoctial line, 1684 — Anon. — Extracts of some letters concerning iron ore; and more particularly of the haematites wrought into iron at Milthorpe forge in Lancashire — Sturmie — To give iron the colour and tincture of copper — Southwell — A letter concerning the magnetic quality acquired by iron upon standing for a long time in the same posture — Leeuwenhoek An historico-physical observation on the waters of Neusohl, which are impregnated with brass, and change iron into brass - Belius A letter concerning melting iron with pit-coal - Moson An account of a mountain of iron ore at Taberg in Sweden - Afcianius Observations on sand iron - Ellicot A letter on the solubility of iron in simple water, by the intervention of fixed air - Lane Account of a specimen of native iron - Steblin Account of the iron ore lately found in Siberia - Pallas Experiments on ignited substances - Whitehurst IRREDUCIBLE CASE. A method of extending Cardan's rule for resolving one case of a cubic equation $x^3 - gx = r$ to the other case of the same equation, which it is not naturally fitted to solve, and which is therefore called the irreducible case - Masereus IRREGULARITIES. Of the irregularities in the planetary motions caused by the mutual attraction of the planets - Walmesly ISINGLASS. An account of the discovery of the manner of making isinglass in Russia; with a particular description of its manufacture in England, from the produce of British fisheries - Jackson ISLAND. An account of the sunk island in the Humber, lately recovered from the sea - Chamberlane Part of a letter concerning a new island lately raised out of the sea near Tercera - Forster On the formation of islands - Dalrymple See Santerini. ISOPERIMETRICAL PROBLEMS. An investigation of a general rule for the resolution of isoperimetrical problems of all orders - Simpson A further attempt to facilitate the resolution of isoperimetrical problems - Simpson ISTHMUS. Letter relating to that isthmus, or neck of land, which is supposed to have joined England and France in former times, where now is the passage between Dover and Calais - Wallis ISTRIA. Observations in travels from Venice through Ist Jui Istria, Dalmatia, Greece, and the Archipelago, to Smyrna — Vernon Italy. Letter concerning the state of learning, and several particulars observed by him lately in Italy — Silviste — Some curious remarks in his travels through Italy — More — An investigation of the difference between the present temperature of the air in Italy, and some other countries, to what it was seventeen centuries ago — Barrington — See Antiquities. Judda. A letter accompanying a new chart of the Red Sea, with two draughts of the roads of Mocha and Judda, and several observations made during a voyage to that sea — Newland — Remarks and observations made on board the ship Kelfall, on a voyage to Judda and Mocha in 1769 — Newland Jugular. An account of the dissection of a dog who had mercury injected into one of the jugulars — Pitt Juices. Queries concerning vegetation, especially the motion of the juices of vegetables — Anon. — Experiment concerning the expansion of blood, and other animal juices — Boyle — Extracts of divers letters touching some inquiries and experiments of the motion of sap in trees, and relating to the question of the circulation of the same — Lister — A letter relating to some particulars in Mr. Lister's communications — Willoughby — Extract of a letter both in relation to the farther discovery of the motion of juices in vegetables, and removing the difference noted in Mr. Willoughby's letter — Anon. — A description of an odd kind of mushroom yeilding a milky juice much hotter upon the tongue than pepper — Lister — An account of the nature and differences of the juices, more particularly, of our English vegetables — Lister — The effects of the opuntia, or prickly pear, and of the Indigo plant in colouring the juices of living animals — Baker Julian Period. A problem for finding the year of the Julian Period by a new and very easy method De Billy A method for finding the number of the Julian Period for any year assigned; the number of the cycle of the sun; the cycle of the moon; and of the indications for the same year being given; together with a demonstration of that method Collins See Style. K. Kamchatka. An account of that part of America which is nearest to the coast of Kamchatka, extracted from the description of Kamchatka, by Professor Krashennicoff. Kapanihane. An account of a moving bog in Ireland. — A true description of the bog of Kapanihane in the county of Limerick, with an account of the motion thereof, June 7, 1697. Kepler's Manuscripts. Account of Solution of his problem His method of computing the moon's parallaxes in solar eclipses, demonstrated and extended to all degrees of the moon's latitude, as also to the assigning the moon's correspondent apparent diameter, together with a concise application of this form of calculation to those eclipses. Kermes. An account of the use of the grain Kermes for colouration. — An observation concerning certain insect husks of the Kermes kind. Account of the kind of insect hatched of the English Kermes above described also the use of these purple insect husks for tingling, together with a comparison of this English purple Kermes, with the scarlet Kermes of the shops. Letter enlarging and correcting his former notes upon Kermes; and withal infinuating his conjectures of cochineal's being a sort of kermes. Kidney. Anatomical observations of an abscess in the liver; a great number of stones in the gall-bag and bilious vessels; an unusual conformation of the emulgents and pelvis; a strange conjunction of both kidneys, and a great dilation of the vena cava. Account of a kidney of an unusual shape and texture, taken out of the body of a man, with observations on horns and glandules in general. An account of a very large diseased kidney, found on the dissection of a lady, with the symptoms of the disease before her death, and an explanation of their phænomena. Of hydatides inclosed with a stony crust in the kidney of a sheep. An account of the dissection of a person who died of an ulcer in the right kidney. An anatomical description of worms, found in the kidneys of wolves. An uncommon dropy, from the want of a kidney; and a large saccus that contained the water. The figures of some very extraordinary calculous concretions formed in the kidney of a woman. An account of a monstrous human foetus, having neither head, heart, lungs, stomach, spleen, pancreas, liver, nor kidneys. See Stone Kilcorny Cave of. A description of the Cave of Kilcorny in the Barony of Burren in Ireland. Kirbythore. See Antiquities. Kircher. Observations upon father Kircher's opinion concerning the burning of the fleet of KIT Marcellus by Archimedes - Porson KITE. Letter concerning an electrical kite Franklin — Answer to several queries concerning his experiment of electricity with a kite Lining KITTING. The phenomena afforded by a newly kittened kidling in the exhausted Receiver Bayle KNEE. An account of an extraordinary tumour in the knee of a person whose leg was taken off Pierce — Two singular cases of diseases at the knee joints successfully treated, the first by topical applications, the second by Warner KNIFE. Case of one who swallowed a knife, which lay in his stomach a year and seven months, and then worked out at an apothecary on his breast Sloane KNIGHT. An account of the magnetical machine contrived by Dr. Knight Fothergill L. LABOURER. Account of some extraordinary tumours upon the head of a labouring man Porson LABRADOR. Particulars of the country of Labrador, extracted from the papers of lieutenant Roger Curtis, of his majesty's sloop the Otter, with a plane-chart of the Coast Curtis — Tract of his majesty's armed brig Lion from England to Davis's Straights and Labrador, with observations for determining the longitude by sun and moon, and error of common reckoning; also the variation of the compass and dip of the needle, as observed during the said voyage in 1776 Pickersgill — Two meteorological journals kept at Nain in 57 degrees north latitude, and Okak, in 57 degrees 30 minutes north latitude, both on the coast of Labrador De la Trobe LABYRINTH. A description of the organ of hearing in the elephant, with the figure and situation of the offices labyrinth and cochlea in the ear of that animal Blair LACERATION. Extract of a letter, containing the particulars of the case of a wound in the cornea, and of a laceration of the uvea in the eye of a woman. **LACERTA.** Letter concerning the circulation of the blood, as seen by the help of a microscope, in lacerta aquatica. An account of lacerta (crocodilus) ventre marsupio donato faucibus merganferis rostrum acumantibus. **LACRYMAE BATAVICAE.** A memoir on the Lacrymae Batavicae; or glass drops, the tempering of steel, and effervescence accounted for by the same principle. **LACTEALS.** Some anatomical observations and experiments concerning the unalterable character of the whiteness of the chyle within the lacteous veins; together with divers particulars observed in the guts, especially several sorts of worms found in them. An account of an experiment made for altering the colour of the chyle in the lacteal veins. Endeavours to prove that the lacteals frequently convey liquors that are not white. Letter concerning powdered blues passing in the lacteal veins. An experiment made for the transmitting of a blue coloured liquor into the lacteals. Account of an experiment, by which it appears that salt of steel does not enter into the lacteal vessels; with remarks. **LAGOPUS.** Observations on the lagopus, or ptarmigan. **LAKES.** Extracts of several letters from Edinburgh, giving an account of an obelisk thrown down by a violent wind, of an extraordinary lake in lord Lovat's lands in Scotland, of Lake Ness, and of a petrifying rivulet. Observations concerning the lake of Mexico. Letter concerning the lake Ness, &c. Observations on the lake Vetter. A description of a large lake called Malholm tarn, near Shipton in Craven, Yorkshire. Account of vegetable balls which grow in a lake near the Humber in Yorkshire, with re- LAM marks by W. Watson LAMA. Experiments made on a great number of animals, with the poison of Lama's and of Tucunas LAMB. Account of a monstrous lamb LAMPAS. Declaration of the Council of the Royal Society passed Nov. 20, 1676, relating to some passages in a late book of Mr. Hook, entitled, Lampas, &c. LAMPS. A discourse concerning the sepulchral lamps of the ancients, shewing the possibility of their being made divers ways An easy contrivance of a lamp to be always kept full whilst it burns LANCASHIRE. Observations on the Roman colonies and stations in Cheshire and Lancashire LAND. Instances, hints, and applications relating to a main point solicited in the preface to the fourth volume; concerning the use may be made of vaults, deep wells, and cold conservatories, to find out the cause, or to promote the generation, of salt, minerals, metals, crystals, gems, stones of divers kinds, and helps to conserve long, or to hasten putrefaction, fertility of any land, &c. Part of a letter concerning the manuring of land in Devonshire with tea sand A letter concerning the manuring of land with fossil shells LANGCHESTER. V. Inscription LANGUAGE. An explication of all the inscriptions in the Palmyrene language and character hitherto published Extracts of some letters on the customs, manners, and language of the Northern Indians of America An account of the Romans' language See Deafness, Speech LANGUEDOC. See Ocean LAPIS CALAMINARIS. An account of digging and preparing the Lapis Calaminaris LAPLAND. A relation of the small creature called sable mice, which have lately come in troops into Lapland, about Thorne, and other places adjacent to the mountains, in innumerable multitudes LARUM. Account of the weavers alarm, vulgo larum - Arderon LARYNGOTOMY. An argument for the more frequent use of laryngotomy, urged from a remarkable cure in chirurgery - Musgrave LATH. A letter concerning a large piece of lath being thrust into the eye of a man who recovered of it - Kepel LATITUDE. The description and use of an instrument for taking the latitude of a place at any time of the day - Graham --- Some considerations on a late treatise intituled A new Set of logarithmic solar Tables, &c., intended for a more commodious method of finding the latitude at sea by two observations of the sun - Pemberton --- A new method of constructing sun-dials for any given latitude, without the assistance of dialling scales or logarithmic calculations - Ferguson LATITUDE OF PLACES. An account of the latitude of Constantinople and Rhodes - Greaves --- An account shewing that the latitude of Nurenburg has continued without sensible alteration for 200 years last past, as likewise the obliquity of the ecliptick, by comparing them with what was observed by B. Walther in 1487 - Wurtzelbaur --- An account of the eclipse of the moon observed at Moscua in Russia, April 5, 1688, compared with the same observed at Leipsick, whereby the longitude of the former is ascertained, together with the latitude of several principal places in the empire of Russia - Timmerman --- A new and exact table, collected from several observations taken in four voyages to Hudson's Bay from London, shewing the variation of the magnetical needle, or sea compass, in the path-way to the said bay, according to the several longitudes and latitudes from 1721 to 1725 - Middleton --- A new and exact table, collected from several observations taken from the year 1721 to 1729, in nine voyages to Hudson's Bay; in North America, shewing the variation of the compass, compass, according to the latitudes and longitudes, accounting the longitude from the meridian of London Observations of latitude and variation taken on board the Hartford, in her passage from Java Head to St. Helena, 1731-2 Observations made of the latitude, variation of the magnetic needle, and wea her, in a voyage from London to Hudson's Bay, 1735 Letter concerning a place in New York for measuring a degree of latitude The effects of cold, together with observations of the longitude, latitude, and declination of the magnetic needle at Prince of Wales Fort upon Churchill River in Hudson's Bay, North America A letter concerning the variation of the magnetic needle, with a set of tables annexed, which exhibit the result of upwards of fifty thousand observations in six periodic reviews from 1700 to 1756, and are adapted to every five degrees of latitude and longitude in the more frequented oceans Letter containing a short account of the measurement of three degrees of latitude under the meridian of Vienna Observations made on the islands of St. John and Cape Breton, to ascertain the longitude and latitude of those places, agreeable to the orders and instructions of the commissioners for trade and plantations Introduction to the following observations made by Ch. Mason and Jer. Dixon, for determining the length of a degree of latitude in the provinces of Maryland and Pennsylvania in North America Length of a degree of latitude in the province of Maryland and Pennsylvania, deduced from the observations of Messieurs Mason and Dixon A determination of the latitude of Stamford in Lincolnshire Astronomical observations made at Leicester for determining the latitude of that place The variation of the compass, containing 1719 observations to, in, and from, the East-Indies, Guinea, West Indies, and Mediterranean, with the latitudes and longitudes at the time of observation — Douglas The latitude of Madras in the East-Indies, deduced from observations — Stephens Two meteorological journals kept at Nain in 57 degree north latitude, and at Okak in 57 degrees 30 minutes north latitude, both on the coast of Labrador — De la Trobe Laudanum. An account of two sorts of Helmontian laudanum, together with the way of F. M Van Helmont preparing his laudanum — Boyle Laurel Water. A letter giving an account of two women being poisoned by the simple distilled water of laurel leaves; and of several experiments upon dogs, by which it appears that this laurel water is the most dangerous poison hitherto known — Madden Some experiments concerning the poisonous quality of the simple distilled water from the lauro-cerasus or common laurel, made upon dogs at Toppingo Hall, Essex; and others made before the Royal Society in their repository — Mortimer Letter on the poison of laurel water — Rutty Lay-Well. An extract of a letter, giving an account of an experiment made in the Bay of Biscay of sinking a bottle, close coked, under various depths of water, and of Lay-well, which ebbs and flows — Oliver Answer to several queries relating to Lay-Well — Oliver Layers. How to multiply crab-stocks, and propagate trees by layers — Tonge Leach. A description of the hirudinella marina, or Sea Leach — Garcin Lead. Of a peculiar lead ore in Germany, and the use thereof — Anon A further account of some rock plants growing in the lead mines of Mendip Hills — Beaumont Some experiments concerning the cohesion of Lead — Defaguliers LEA An account of the case of a man who died of the effects of the fire at Eddystone light-house by melted lead running down his throat Spry Huxham A short account of some specimens of native lead found in a mine of Monmouthshire Morry Chemical experiments and observations on lead-ore Richard Watson LEADEN COFFIN. Vide Antiquities LEARNING. Letter concerning the state of learning, and several particulars observed by him lately in Italy Silvestri LEATHER. Brief directions how to tan leather according to the new invention of the honourable Charles Howard of Norfolk, experimented and approved of by divers of the principal tanners using Leadenhall-Market Howard An improved method of tanning leather Macbride LEAVES. A way of colouring leaves, fruit, &c. Tonge Two observations, the one concerning the effects of a poisonous root, the other concerning the virtues of the leaves of hemlock Ray An account of the veins and arteries of leaves Nicholls An observation on the double fibres observable in the skeletons prepared from green leaves Hollman Conjectures on the use of double fibres in some leaves, &c. Hollman LEECH. Of the long continuance of one alive in the vacuum made in the pneumatical engine Boyle The anatomical history of the Leech Postgate LEG. An account of stitching the great tendon between the calf of the leg and heel, with its union and cure, after an entire division of it; with remarks Cowper A letter concerning a woman of 62 years of age, that lost her leg and greatest part of her thigh, by a gangrene Calpe An account of an extraordinary tumour in the knee of a person whose leg was taken off Peirce An account of a new-invented instrument for fractured legs — Sharp Legion. A new contrivance for taking levels - Desaguliers A description of a water-level to be fixed to Davis's quadrant, whereby an observation may be taken at sea in thick and hazy weather without seeing the horizon - Leigh The description and use of an apparatus added as an improvement to Davis's quadrant, consisting of a mercurial level for taking the co-altitude of sun or star at sea without the usual assistance of the sensible horizon which frequently is obscured - Leigh LEVERS. An account of some new experiments in electricity, containing, 1. An enquiry whether vapour be a conductor of electricity. 2. Some experiments to ascertain the direction of the electric matter in the discharge of the Leyden bottle. 3. Experiments on the lateral explosion in the discharge of the Leyden bottle. 4. The description and use of a new prime conductor. 5. Miscellaneous experiments made principally in 1771 and 1772. 6. A letter concerning the petrefac- tions of Lough Neagh in Ireland: to which is annexed a letter from the right reverend doctor George Berkley, lord bishop of Cloyne, to Thomas Prior, Esq. **LOWDELL.** The case of Grace Lowdell, aged about sixty, who had an extraordinary tumour on her thigh **LUMBAGO.** The history of a convulsive rheumatic lumbago **LUMBRICUS HYDROPICUS,** or an essay to prove that the hydatides, often met with in morbid animal bodies, are a species of worms or imperfect animals — **Latus,** or a discourse on the jointed worm — **Teres,** or some anatomical observations on the round worm bred in human bodies **LUMINOUS APPEARANCES IN THE AIR.** Vide *Lights* (Astronomical) **LUMINOUS EMANATIONS.** Vide *Lights* (Natural History) **LUNATIONS.** Short and easy methods for finding the quantity of time contained in any given number of mean lunations, and the number of mean lunations in any given quantity of time **LUNGS.** An experiment of preserving animals alive by blowing through their lungs with bellows Some anatomical observations about the structure of the lungs of frogs, tortoises, &c., and perfecter animals, as also on the texture of the spleen, &c. — Letter concerning the structure of the lungs — An account of some animals, that having lungs are yet without the arterious vein; together with some other curious particulars — An account of an experiment of the injection of Mercury into the blood, and its ill effects on the lungs — Observations about the polypus of the lungs with Dr. Lister's opinion — Letter concerning a substance coughed up resembling... LUN LUS — A letter concerning the cure of an apostemation of the lungs — Wright — An answer — Cowper — Observations on a treatise of M. Hevelius, designed to prove that the lungs do not divide and expand the blood, but on the contrary cool and condense it — Nicholas — A case wherein part of the lungs were coughed up — Watson — Case of a lad shot through the lungs drawn up by N. Peters — Hallett — Observations on a case published in the last volume of the Medical Essays, &c. of recovering a man dead in appearance by distending the lungs with air — Fothergill — Cases of the remarkable effects of blisters in lessening the quickness of the pulse in coughs attended with an infarction of the lungs and a fever — Whytt — Case of an extraneous body forced into the lungs — Martin — An uncommon anatomical observation of a defect in the right lobe of the lungs — Paitoni — An account of a monstrous human foetus, having neither head, heart, lungs, stomach, spleen pancreas, liver, nor kidney — Le Cat Luni-Solar Tables. Emendations and notes upon the antient astronomical observations of Albatenius, with the restoration of his luni-solar tables — Halley Lunula. IX 316 VI 2 203 III 262 — M. **Machines (Chirurgical).** The description and draught of a machine for reducing fractures of the thigh - Description of a machine for dressing and curving unwieldy patients An account of the extraction of three inches and ten lines of the bone of the upper arm, which was followed by a regeneration of the bony matter; with a description of a machine made use of to keep the upper and the lower pieces of the bone at their proper distances during the time that the regeneration was taking place; and which may also be of service in fractures happening near the head of that bone **Machines (Mechanical).** An account of a catadioptrick telescope, made by John Hadley, Esq., with the description of a machine contrived for applying it to use An account of a new machine called the marine surveyor, intended for the mensuration of the way of a ship in the sea, more correctly than by the log, or any other method hitherto used for that purpose, together with several testimonials setting forth the usefulness of this invention Account of a machine to represent eclipses of the earth A scheme of a diary of the weather, together with draughts and descriptions of machines subservient thereto A description of a machine to blow fire by the fall of water A machine for sounding the sea at any depth, or in any part, invented by Mr. William Cock in the year 1738, in a voyage to Georgia Account of a machine to write down extempore voluntaries, or other pieces of music An account of a machine for killing whales | Transf. | Abridg. | |---------|---------| | XLI 562 | IX 254 | | XLII 364 | — 272 | | LVI 270 | XXXII 303 | | XXXVI 45 | VI 456 | | XLI 781 | VIII 157 | | XLIII 1 | XI 1226 | | — 315 | X 205 | | XLIV 146 | — 261 | | — 445 | — 265 | | XLVII 429 | Some | Some experiments upon a machine for measuring the way of a ship at sea - Account of a new megameter - Boscovich MELLOON. Account of one Edward Melloon, born at Port Leicester in Ireland, who was of an extraordinary size - Musgrave MELONS. Way of ordering melons De la Quintinie — Further directions - De la Quintinie — Some microscopical observations and curious re- marks on the vegetation and exceeding quick propagation of moldiness, on the substance of a melon — Bradley — A letter concerning the vegetation of melon-seed forty-two years old — Trieuvala — Letter concerning the vegetation of melon-seed thirty-three years old — Gale MEMBRANES. A further account concerning the existence of veins in all kinds of plants; together with a discovery of the membranous substance of those veins, and some acts in plants resembling those of sense; and also the agreement of the venal juice in vegetables with the blood of animals, &c. — Lister — Microscopical observations on the blood-vessels and membranes of the intestines — Levenhock — Observations upon the membranes enclosing the fasciculi of fibres, into which a muscle is divided — Levenhock MEMORY. Account of the strength of memory when applied with due attention — Wallis MENDIP. A curious description of the strata observed in the coal-mines of Mendip in Somersetshire — Strachey MENE. Letter concerning the stocking the river Mene with oysters — Rowlands MENSES. A letter containing the case of a woman who had her menses regularly to 70 years of age — Yonge MENSTRUA: A discourse on this problem; why bodies dissolved in menstrua specifically lighter than themselves swim therein W. Molyneux With some reflections — T. Molyneux MERCATOR. An easy mechanical way to divide the nautical meridian line in Mercator's projection, with an account of the relation of the same meridian line to the curva catenaria — Perks — Remarks on the censure of Mercator's chart, in a posthumous work of Mr. West of Exeter — Dunn A defence of Mercator's chart against the censure of Mr. West — Mountaine MERCURIAL LEVEL. The description and use of an apparatus added as an improvement to Davis's quadrant, consisting of a mercurial level, for taking the altitude of sun or star, at sea, with- out the usual assistance of the sensible horizon; which frequently is obscured - Leigh **Mercury.** Part of a letter concerning the strange effects from the eating Dog Mercury, with remarks thereon by Hans Sloane Baxter (Mineral) Letter concerning the mines of Mercury in Friuli Pape (Medicine) An account of an experiment of the injection of Mercury into the blood, and its ill effects on the lungs Moulin An account of the dissection of a dog who had Mercury injected into one of the jugulars Pitt A Letter containing some experiments made upon mad dogs with Mercury James An account of what was observed upon opening the corpse of a person who had taken several ounces of crude Mercury internally; and of a plum-stone lodged in the coats of the rectum Madden An account of a large glandular tumor in the pelvis; and of the pernicious effects of crude Mercury given inwardly to the patient Cantwell **Mercury (Barometer)** A relation of some mercurial observations, and their result Oldenburg A prospect of the weather, winds, and height of the Mercury in the barometer, on the first day of the month, and of the whole rain in every month in 1703, and beginning of 1704 at Townley in Lancashire, by R. Townley, and at Upminster, by W. Derham Townley and Derham Several experiments on the mercurial phosphorous Hauksbee **Mercury (the planet)** An observation of a transit of Mercury under the sun, Oct. 31, 1690, at Nuremberg Wurtzelbaur An account of the appearance of Mercury, passing over the sun's disk, on the 29th of October, 1723, determining the mean motion, and fixing the nodes of that planet's orb Halle memoir read at the academy of sciences at Paris by M. de Barros, concerning certain phenomena, observed by him at Paris in the last transit of Mercury over the sun Short The difference of longitude over the sun, Oct. 25, 1743 Winthrop An account of the transit of Mercury at Norriton in Pennsylvania, Nov. 9, 1769 Smith Account of an observation of the transit of Mercury over the sun, Nov. 9, 1769, at Cambridge in New England Winthrop Meridian. Of a correspondence to be procured for the finding out the true distance of the sun and moon, from the earth by the parallax observed under, or near, the same meridian Oldenburg Letter proposing a new place for the first meridian dian, and pretending to evince the equality of all natural days, as also to shew a way of knowing the true place of the moon Professor of Seville Answer to the above letter Flamsteed An instrument for seeing the sun, moon, or stars pass the meridian of any place, useful for setting watches in all parts of the world with the greatest exactness, to correct sun-dials, to assist in the discovery of the longitudes of places Observations on the meridian height of the sun, to investigate the elevation of the pole at Lisbon The difference in time of the meridians of diverse places, computed from observations of the eclipses of Jupiter's satellites See Longitude Meridian Line. An easy demonstration of the analogy of the logarithmic tangents to the meridian line, or sum of the secants, with various methods for computing the same to the utmost exactness Letter concerning some supposed alteration of the meridian line; which may affect the declination of the magnetic needle, and the poles elevation New way of drawing the meridian line Letter concerning drawing the meridian line by the pole star, and finding the hour by the same An easy mechanical way to divide the nautical meridian line in Mercator's projection, with an account of the relation of the same meridian line to the curva catenaria Letter containing an explanation of the late Dr. Halley's demonstration of the analogy of the logarithmic tangents to the meridian line, or the sum of the secants Mesentery. Account of an unusual rupture of the mesentery Letter concerning a child who had its intestines, mesentery, &c. in the cavity of the thorax Metal (in general) A description of the uses of a certain powder for yielding very close and smooth metal, and of easy carriage, &c. for casting of guns A catalogue of fossils, shells, metals, minerals, &c. which J. J. Scheuzbzer of Zurich sent to J. Petiver Experiments concerning the effects of air passed through red-hot metals The specific gravity of metalline cubes, in comparison of their like bulks of water Some observations towards composing a natural history of mines and metals A second letter containing farther observations towards composing a natural history of mines and metals The description and manner of using an instrument for measuring the degrees of the expansion of metals by heat Metal. (Use of, in making instruments) A new method of improving and perfecting catadioptrical telescopes, by forming the speculums of glass instead of metal A discourse concerning the usefulness of thermometers in chemical experiments, and concerning the principles on which the thermometers now in use have been constructed; together with the description and uses of a metalline thermometer newly invented by Mortimer A letter concerning a metalline thermometer in the museum of the Society at Spalding A description of a metalline thermometer Directions for making the best composition for the metals of reflecting telescopes; together with a description of the process for grinding, polishing, and giving the great speculum the true parabolic curve The principal properties of the engine for turning ovals in wood or metal, and of the instrument for drawing ovals upon paper demonstrated Metal. (Chemistry) How terrestrial streams may be the generative cause both of minerals and metals, and of all the peculiarities of springs A continuation of the discourse concerning vitreol, shewing, that vitriol is usually produced by sulphur, acting on and coagulating with a metal, and then making out, that alum is likewise the result of the said sulphur; as also evincing, that vitriol, sulphur, and alum do agree in the saline principle; and lastly, declaring the nature of the salt in brimstone, and whence it is derived. Experiments and observations on the agreement between the specific gravities of the several metals and their colours when united to glass, as well as those of their other proportions. An account of rings consisting of all the prismatic colours, made by explosions on the surface of pieces of metal. Metaphysics. Principia dynamica five principia mechanices. Meteors. An account of a considerable meteor seen in many distant places in England, Sept. 20, 1676. An account of an extraordinary meteor, or kind of dew resembling butter, that fell last winter and spring in Ireland. A letter giving an account of some appearances in the heavens in Ireland, 1708. A letter giving an account of a meteor which was seen in Yorkshire, and other neighbouring counties, upon May 18, 1710. Account of several meteors or lights in the sky. A letter giving a relation of a fiery meteor seen in Jamaica, to strike into the earth; with remarks on the weather, earthquakes, &c. of that island. An account of the extraordinary meteor seen all over England, on the 19th of March, 1718-9, with a demonstration of the uncommon height thereof. A description of the great meteor seen on the 6th of March, 1715-6. Letter concerning the mines of Mercury in Friuli Of the mineral of Liege yielding both brimstone and vitriol, and the way of extracting them out of it, used at Liege An account how adits and mines are wrought at Liege without air-shafts Articles of enquiries concerning mines Observations made in mines and at sea, occasioning a conjecture about the origin of wind An answer to some enquires formerly published concerning mines Narrative of the minerals of Mexico A particular account of divers minerals sent from the lately burning Mount Aetna Account of the copper mine in Hern Ground in Hungary A relation concerning the quicksilver mines of Friuli; confirming as well the account given on that subject, vol. I. p. 21. as enlarging the same, with some additions Instances, hints, and applications relating to a main point solicited in the preface to this fourth volume; concerning the use may be made of vaults, deep well. cold conservatories, to find out the cause or to promote the generation of salt, minerals, metals, crystal, gems, stones of divers kinds, and helps to conserve long, or to hasten putrefaction, fertility of any kind of ground, &c. A relation concerning the sal-gemmæ mines in Poland How terrestrial streams may be the generative cause both of minerals and metals, and of all the peculiarities of springs Directions and enquiries, with their answers, concerning the mines, &c. of Hungary, Transf. | Abridg. ---|--- XLIX i | X 247 XVII 695 | II 551 I 21 | I 498 I 45 | II 577 II 481 | II 530 — 79 | — 372 — 342 | — 105 — 525 | — 573 III 767 | III 574 — 817 | III 588 IV 1041 | II 390 V 1042 | V 562 IV 1080 | IV 579 — 1135 | — V 1099 | II 524 V 1154 | Transylvania, Austria, and other countries neighbouring to those Olænburgh and Brown. An account of some mineral observations touching the mines of Cornwall and Devon; wherein is described the art of training a load; the art and manner of digging the ore, and the way of dressing and blowing tin. An account of two uncommon mineral substances found in some coal and iron mines in England. Some observations and experiments about vitriol, tending to prove the nature of that substance, and to give further light in the enquiry after the principles and properties of other minerals. Two letters concerning rock plants, and their growth. A description of the diamond mines. A relation of the tin-mines, and working of tin in the county of Cornwall. A further account of some rock plants growing in the lead mines of Mendip Hills. An account of a strange preservation of four men in a mine 24 days without any food. A catalogue of fossils, shells, metals, minerals, &c. which J. J. Scheuchzer of Zurich sent to Mr. Petiver. A curious description of the strata observed in the coal mines of Mendip in Somersetshire. Some observations towards composing a natural history of mines and metals. A second letter to Dr. Rutty, containing further observations towards composing a natural history of mines and metals. An account of the several strata of earths and fossils found in sinking the mineral well at Holt. Some observations on the mines of Spain and Germany. A short account of some specimens of native lead found in a mine in Monmouthshire. Barometrical observations on the depth of the mines in the Hartz. Speculations of the changes likely to be discovered in the earth and moon by their respective inhabitants - Auzout Of the correspondency, to be procured, for the finding out the true distance of the sun and moon from the earth, by the parallax observed under (or near) the same meridian - Oldenburg A method for finding the number of the Julian period for any year assigned, the number of the cycle of the sun, the cycle of the moon, and of the indictions, for the same year, being given, together with a demonstration of that method - Euler — A resolution of a general Proposition for deter- mining the hourly alteration of the position of the terrestrial equator, from the attraction of the sun and moon: with some remarks on the solutions given by other authors to that dif- ficult and important problem — Simpson — A letter concerning observations to be made on the parallax of the moon at St. Helena, and recommending the same to be made at Paris and Greenwich Le Caille and Maskelyne — Certain reasons for a lunar atmosphere Dunn — An account of an apple of the moon to the planet Jupiter observed at Chelsea Dunn — Of the moon's distance and parallax Murdock — Concise rules for computing the effects of re- fraction and parallax in varying the apparent distance of the moon from the sun or a star; also an easy rule of approximation for com- puting the distance of the moon from a star, the longitudes and latitudes of both being given with demonstrations of the same Maskelyne — Short and easy methods for finding the quantity of time contained in any given number of mean lunations, and the number of mean lu- nations in any given quantity of time Ferguson — An essay on the connection between the paral- laxes of the sun and moon; their densities; and their disturbing forces on the ocean Murdock — Kepler's method of computing the moon's pa- rallaxes in solar eclipses, demonstrated and extended to all degrees of the moon's latitude, as also to the assigning the moon's corre- spondent apparent diameter, together with a concise application of this form of calculation to those eclipses Pemberton — Astronomical observations relating to the moun- tains of the moon Herschel Moon. (Applied to finding the longitude) An instrument for seeing the sun, moon, or stars pass the meridian of any place; useful for setting watches in all parts of the world with the greatest exactness, to correct sun-dials, to assist in the discovery of the longitude of places — Derham A letter containing the results of observations of the distance of the moon from the sun and fixed stars, made in a voyage from England to the island of St. Helena, in order to determine the longitude of the ship from time to time; together with the whole process of computation used on this occasion — Maskelyne Letter giving an account of observations at sea for finding out the longitude by the moon — Horsey Tract of his majesty's armed brig Leon from England to Davis's Straights and Labrador, with observations for determining the longitude by sun and moon, and error of common reckoning reckoning; also the variation of the compass and dip of the needle as observed during the said voyage in 1776 - Pickering Moors. A summary of the general laws of motion Theory of motion A summary account of the laws of motion Some propositions on the parabolic motion of projectiles, written in 1710 (Astronomy) A letter concerning the moon's motion A letter concerning the mean motion of the moon's apogee An account of a prize of 100 ducats offered by the Academy of Sciences at Petersburg, for the best answer to the question, "Whether the theory of Sir Isaac Newton is sufficient to explain all the irregularities which are found in the motion of the moon?" Of the irregularities in the planetary motions caused by the mutual attraction of the planets An essay on the connection between the parallaxes of the sun and moon; their densities; and their disturbing forces on the ocean (Mechanics) Letter concerning a movement that measures time after a peculiar manner, with an account of the reason of the said motion A discourse proving from experiments, that the larger the wheels of a coach, &c. are, the more easily they may be drawn over a stone, or such like obstacle that lies in the way Observations on a French paper concerning perpetual motion A discourse concerning gravity, and its properties, wherein the descent of heavy bodies, and the motion of projects, is briefly but fully handled; together with the solution of a problem of great use in gunnery Further remarks on the instrument proposed by an anonymous French author for effecting a perpetual motion — Papin An answer to the author of the perpetual motion — Papin Experiments about the motion of pendulums in vacuo — Dehant Remarks of some attempts made toward a perpetual motion — Desaguliers The greatest effect of engines, with uniformly accelerated motions considered — Blake An experimental enquiry concerning the natural powers of water and wind to turn mills and other machines depending on a circular motion — Smeaton A letter containing a demonstration of a law of motion, in the case of a body deflected by two forces, tending constantly to two fixed points — Robertson A new theory of the rotatory motion of bodies affected by forces disturbing such motion — Landen An investigation of the principles of progressive and rotatory motion — Vince (Force of moving bodies) A letter concerning an experiment whereby it has been attempted to shew the falsity of the common opinion, in relation to the force of bodies in motion — Pemberton An account of some experiments made to prove that the force of moving bodies is proportionable to their velocities — Desaguliers Animadversions upon some experiments relating to the force of moving bodies; with two new experiments on the same subject — Desaguliers A remark upon the new opinion relating to the forces of moving bodies, in the case of the collision of non-elastic bodies — Eames Remarks upon a supposed demonstration, that the moving forces of the same body are not as the velocities, but as the squares of the velocities — Eames A letter occasioned by the present controversy among mathematicians, concerning the proportion of velocity and force in bodies in motion — Samuel Clarke An account of an experiment contrived by G. X x 2 J. Graveshamde, relating to the force of moving bodies, shewn to the Royal Society by Desaguliers An enquiry into the measure of the force of bodies in motion; with a proposal of an experimentum crucis to decide the controversy about it. An experimental examination of the quantity and proportion of mechanic power, necessary to be employed in giving different degrees of velocity to heavy bodies from a state of rest. Reflections on the communication of motion by impact and gravity. (Motion of fluids) An account of the motion of running water. A defence of the dissertation of the motion of running water, against the animadversions of P. A. Michelotti. Remarks upon some experiments in hydraulics, which seem to prove that the forces of equal moving bodies are as the squares of their velocities. Of the measure and motion of running water. With the conclusion. (Motion of the earth) An account of a controversy between Stephano de Angelis of Padua, and J. B. Riccioli, concerning the motion of the earth. Extract of a letter touching his thoughts of Mr. Hooke's observations for proving the motion of the earth. Extract of another letter relating to the same subject. (Electricity) An account of the repetition of an experiment touching motion, given bodies included in a glass, by the approach of a finger near its outside; with other experiments on the effluvia of glass. (Heat) An experiment to examine what figure and celerity of motion begetteth or increaseth light and flame. Two letters concerning the rotatory motion of glass tubes about their axes when placed in a certain manner before the fire. Judgment touching the apertures of object-glasses, and their proportions in respect of the several lengths of telescopes, together with a table thereof Luxoni I. 55 I 191 Instance Instance to Mr. Hooke for communicating a contrivance of making, with a glass of a sphere of 20 or 40 feet diameter, a telescope, drawing several hundred feet; and his offer of recompensing that secret with another, teaching to measure, with a telescope, the distances of objects upon the earth. A way for Myopes to use telescopes without eye-glasses, an object-glass alone becoming as useful to them, and sometimes more, than a combination of glasses.
