Observatory. Letter concerning the remains of the observatory of the famous Tycho Brahe. The difference of longitude between the Royal Observatories of Greenwich and Paris, determined by the observations of the transits of Mercury over the sun in 1723, 1736, 1746, 1753. Description and use of a new-constructed equatorial or portable observatory. A comparative table of the corresponding observations of the first satellite, made in the principal observatories. An account of the Bramin's observatory at Bénares. Obstruction. A method proposed to restore the hearing, when injured from an obstruction of the tuba eustachiana. Occultation. An occultation of Mars, and certain fixed stars, observed at Danzig, Sept. 1, 1676. An observation of Mars covered by the moon, Aug. 21, 1676, at Greenwich. An account of an occultation of Venus by the moon. moon, Sept. 19, 1729, at Berlin Kirchius Observations of the occultation of Mars by the moon, Oct. 7, 1736, Fleet-street Graham Covent-garden Bevis Observations of an occultation of Palilicius, at Berlin, Dec. 23, 1738 Kirchius Wittenberg Weidler An occultation of Jupiter and his satellites by the moon, Oct. 28, 1740 Graham An account of an occultation of Jupiter by the moon, June 6, 1744, London Bevis An observation on an occultation of Cor Leonis, by the moon, on Thursday, March 12, 1747, in Surry-street, in the Strand, London, with a reflecting telescope, made by Mr. Short, which magnified above 100 times Bevis An occultation of the planet Venus by the moon in the day-time, observed at London, April 16, 1751 Bevis Observations of the occultations of Venus by the moon, April 16, 1751 Bradley Account of occultations of the fixed stars by the moon, that will happen in 1763, proper to determine the exact difference of longitude betwixt London, Paris, and Greenwich De la Lande Occultation of fixed stars by the moon, observed at Greenwich, 1769 Maskelyne An account of an occultation of the star ζ Tauri by the moon, observed at Leicester Ludlam Occultation of α and γ Tauri by the moon Lexell See particular Occultations in their Places Ocean. Advice touching the conjunction of the Ocean with the Mediterranean Petit A narrative of the conjunction of the two seas, the Ocean, and the Mediterranean, by a channel cut out through Languedoc in France Oldenburg Additions to the narrative about the conjunction of the ocean and the Mediterranean, by a channel in France Froideur An essay on the connection between the parallaxes of the sun and moon, their densities, and their disturbing forces on the ocean **Odours.** Letter declaring that he, as well as many others, have not been able to make odours pass through glass by means of electricity, and giving a particular account of Professor Bose, at Wittemberg, his experiments of beatification, or causing a glory to appear round a man's head by electricity. An account of experiments relating to odours passing through electrified globes and tubes With an account of the result of some experiments made here with globes and tubes, transmitted by Mr. Winkler, in order to verify the facts above mentioned **Oenanthe Aquatica.** Critical observations concerning the oenanthe aquatica succo virose crocante, of Lobel **Oil.** An account of the making pitch, tar, and oil, out of a blackish stone in Shropshire Letter concerning the efficacy of oil of olives in curing the bite of vipers An account of some cases of dropsies cured by sweet oil **Oil of Oranges.** An account of an experiment touching the direction of a drop of the oil of oranges, between two glass planes, towards any side of them that is nearest pressed together An account of an experiment, concerning the angle required to suspend a drop of oil of oranges, at certain stations, between two glass planes, placed in the form of a wedge **Okak.** Two meteorological journals kept at Nain, in 57 degrees north latitude, and at Okak, in 57 degrees 38 minutes, north latitude, both on the coast of Labrador **Ombriae.** An account of certain transparent pebbles, mostly of the shape of the ombriae **Ombrometer.** Description of the ombrometer **OME** **OPT** **Omentum.** Observations on a large omentum *Huxham* XXXIII 60 VII 518 **Opal.** Letter about the making of counterfeit opal *Colepeper* III 743 III 685 **Ophris.** An account of a species of ophris, supposed to be the plant mentioned by Gronovius in the Flora Virginica, p. 185 *Ehret* LII 81 **Opium.** Of the use of opium amongst the Turks *Smyth* XIX 288 II 643 — An account of a person who took a great quantity of opium without causing sleep *Anon.* XXII 999 V 357 **Opossum.** Carigueya seu Marsupiale Americanum, or the anatomy of an opossum *Tyson* XX 105 II 881 — The anatomy of a male opossum with observations *Cowper* XXIV 1565 — The anatomy of a male opossum, with observations on the opossum, and a new division of terrestrial brute animals, particularly those that have feet formed like hands, where an account is given of some animals not yet described *Tyson* — V 177 — A letter to Dr. Tyson, giving an account of the anatomy of those parts of a male opossum that differ from the female *Cowper* — 1576 — 169 **Optick Glasses.** An account of an improvement of optick glasses *Ciampani* I 2 I 193 — Considerations upon Mr. Hooke's new instrument for grinding of optick glasses *Auzout* — 56 — 215 Answered *Hooke* — 63 — 192 — A further account touching Signor Campani's book and performances about optick glasses *Auzout* — 69 Sig. Campani's answer, and M. Auzout's animadversions thereon — 74 — Of M. Hevelius's promise of imparting to the world his invention of making optick glasses, and of the hopes given by M. Hugens of Zulichem, to perform something of the like nature; as also of the expectations conceived of some ingenious persons in England, to improve telescopes *Hevelius Hugens & Du Sons* — 98 — 193 — An account of the tryals, made in Italy, of Campani's new optick glasses *Anon.* I 138 I 193 — A contest between two artists about optick glasses *Campani & Divini* — 209 I 193 | Title | Transl. | Abridg. | |----------------------------------------------------------------------|---------|---------| | An observation of optick glasses made of rock-crystal | I 362 | I 195 | | An account of the invention of grinding optic and burning glasses of a figure not spherical | III 631 | — 194 | | A letter concerning an optical experiment, conducive to a decayed sight | — 727 | III 41 | | Another, confirming the former, and adding some other observations about sight | — 729 | II 864 | | A note relating to the above | — 765 | | | Another note on the same, about the small empty tubes | — 802 | | | A contrivance to make the picture of anything appear on a wall, cup-board, or within a picture-frame, &c. in the midst of a light room | — 741 | I 206 | | Letters about an optic problem of Alhazen | VIII 6119 | — 172 | | Continuation of the letters | — 6140 | II 290 | | Some optical assertions concerning the rainbow | X 386 | I 315 | | An instance of the excellence of the modern algebra in the resolution of the problem of finding the foci of optic glasses universally | XVII 960 | — 183 | | An account of an optical experiment made before the Royal Society | XXXII 206 | VI 145 | | Experiments made in August, 1728, before the Royal Society upon occasion of Signor Rizzetti's opticks with an account of that book | XXXV 607 | — 110 | | An observation made in opticks | LIII 229 | | | See Light and Colours | | | | Optic Nerve. likewise a description of a new species of sea pen found on the coast of South Carolina, with observations on sea pens in general Ellis **Pen-Park-Hole.** A description of Pen-Park-Hole, in Gloucestershire Southwell **Pennsylvania.** Observations on the oyster banks of Pennsylvania Bartram **Pepper.** A description of an odd kind of mushroom yielding a milky juice, much hotter upon the tongue than pepper Lifter Observations concerning some little animals observed in rain, well, tea, and snow water; Letter concerning a pin, found in the gizzard of a fowl - Regnart — Of an inguinal rupture, with a pin in the appendix cæci incrustated with stone - Amyand — An extraordinary case of three pins swallowed by a girl, and discharged at her shoulder - Lyons PINE APPLES. On the culture of pine apples - Baftard PINIONS. Account of advantages of a newly invented machine much varied in its effects, and very useful for determining the perfect proportion between different moveables acting by levers and wheel and pinion - Le Cerf PIPES. An account of several experiments concerning the running of water in pipes, as it is retarded by friction and intermixed air; with a description of a new machine, whereby pipes may be cleared of air, as the water runs along, without stand-pipes, or the help of any hand - Desaguliers — A proposal for warming rooms by the steam of boiling water conveyed in pipes along the walls - Cook — Short and easy methods of finding the quantity and weight of water contained in a full pipe of any given height and diameter of bore, and consequently to find what degree of power would be required to work a common pump, or any other hydraulic engine, when the diameter of the pump-bore, and the height to which the water is to be raised, are given - Ferguson PITCH. An account of the making pitch, tar, and oil out of a blackish stone in Shropshire - Ele — The way of making pitch, tar, rosin, and turpentine near Marteilles - Bent PITH. Instances shewing the correspondence of the pith and timber with the seed of the plant; as also of the bark or sap in the bark with the pulp of the fruit, or some encompassing coat or cod containing the seed - Beal PITKEATHLY. Planets. On the method of determining the places of the planets by observing their near appulses to the fixed stars — Halley An inquiry concerning the figure of such planets as revolve about an axis, supposing the density continually to vary from the centre towards the surface — Clairaut A new and peculiar method of calculating eclipses of the earth, and of any appulses of the moon to planets and fixed stars — Gersten Letter concerning the contraction of the orbits of the planets — Euler A treatise on the precession of the equinoxes, and, in general, on the motion of the nodes, and the alteration of the inclination of the orbit of a planet to the ecliptic — Silvabell Of the irregularities in the planetary motions, caused by the mutual attraction of the planets — Walmley See particular Planets in their Places Plants. Ranby A letter, giving an account of two women being poisoned by the simple distilled water of laurel leaves, and of several experiments upon dogs; by which it appears that this laurel water is the most dangerous poison hitherto known. Account of a pond in Somersetshire to which pigeons resort, but cattle will not drink at it Further account of the (pond) vitriolate water, with some particulars touching waters An attempt to account for the rising and falling of the water of some ponds near the sea, or ebbing or flowing rivers, where the water is lowest in the pond, at the time of high water in the sea or river, and the water is the highest in the pond, at the time of low water in the sea or river; as also for the increasing or decreasing of the water of such pools or brooks as are highest in the dry seasons, and lowest in the rainy seasons; with an experiment to illustrate the solution of the phenomena Poplar. Observations on the black poplar Population. An extract of two essays in political arithmetick, concerning the comparative magnitudes of London and Paris A further assertion of the propositions and vindication from the objections of some learned persons of the French nation An account of the number of people in the counties of Armagh, Louth, and Meath, and the city of Dublin; with an estimate of the number of people in the kingdom of Ireland, 1695-6 An account of the Roman clergy in Ireland according to the return made 1698 The number of people in the city of Bristol calculated from the burials for ten years successively, and also from the number of houses A letter concerning the number of inhabitants within the London bills of mortality Answer to some queries respecting the population of Constantinople A letter concerning the number of people in England A letter concerning the present increase of the people in Britain and Ireland — Brakenridge An extract of the register of the parish of Great Shefford, in Berkshire, for ten years; with observations on the same — Forster Letter concerning the number of people in England — Forster An answer to the account of the numbers and increase of the people of England — Brakenridge Of the increase and mortality of the inhabitants in the island of Madeira — Thomas Heberden Observations on the expectations of lives, the increase of mankind, the influence of great towns on population, and particularly the state of London with respect to healthfulness and number of inhabitants — Price Extract of a letter concerning the increase of population in Anglesey — Panton Observations on the state of population in Manchester, and other adjacent places — Percival Observations on the state of population in Manchester, and other adjacent places concluded — Percival A supplement to a paper, entitled, "observations on the population of Manchester" — Percival Observations on the population and diseases of Chester, in the year 1774 — Haygarth See Mortality Porcupine Quills. Short and easy methods for finding the quantity quantity and weight of water contained in a full pipe of any given height and diameter of bore; and consequently to find what degree of power would be required to work a common pump, or any other hydraulic engine, when the diameter of the pump-bore, and the height to which the water is to be raised therein, are given. **Precious Stones.** Some remarks on the precious stone called the turquoise Some observations upon gems or precious stones; more particularly such as the ancients used to engrave upon **Precipices or Cliffs.** Extract of a letter containing observations on the precipices and cliffs on the north-east coast of Norfolk **Preservation of Bodies.** See Death. **Pressure.** Some experiments and observations on the force of the pressure of the water at great depths **Prickleback.** Abstract of a letter concerning some observations made on the bansticle or prickleback, and also on fish in general **Prickly Pear.** The effects of the opuntia, or prickly pear, and of the indigo plant in colouring the juices of living animals **Printing.** That Costerus first invented printing 1430 Some observations concerning the invention and progress of printing to 1465 An essay on the invention of printing, by John Bagford; with an account of his collections for the same An account of Mr. Le Blon's principles of printing in imitation of paintings, and of weaving of tapestry in the same manner as brocades The description of an antique metal stamp, in the collection of the Duke of Richmond, being one of the instances how near the Romans had arrived to the art of printing; with some remarks **Prism.** An account of rings, consisting of all the prismatic colours, made by electrical explosions on the surface of pieces of metal PRISM. An account of two giants causeways, or groups of prismatic basaltine columns, and other volcanic concretions in the Venetian State in Italy; with some remarks on the characters of those and other similar bodies, and on the physical geography of the countries in which they are found Account of a new instrument for measuring small angles called the prismatic micrometer PROBLEM. See Math motics PROBOSCI. Microscopical observations on the proboscis of fleas PROJECTILES. A discourse concerning gravity and its properties, wherein the descent of heavy bodies, and the motion of projects, is briefly, but fully handled; together with the solution of a problem of great use in gunnery Some propositions on the parabolic motion of projectiles written in 1710 The motion of projectiles near the earth's surface considered, independent of the properties of the conic-sections PROPAGATION. Letter concerning the seeds of plants, with observations on the manner of the propagation of plants and animals Some microscopical observations and curious remarks on the vegetation and exceeding quick propagation of mouldings on the substance of a melon A letter concerning the propagation of mistletoe PROPORTION. of the same, kept at the Royal Society Experiments and observations on the agreement between the specific gravities of the several metals, and their colours, when united to glass, as well as those of A letter concerning an extraordinary fish called in Russia, quab, and concerning the stones called crabs eyes - Baker QUADRABLE. Letter concerning the spaces in the cycloid, which are perfectly quadrable - Wallis QUADRANT. The description of a new quadrant for taking altitudes without an horizon, either at sea or land - Elton — A spirit level to be fixed to a quadrant for taking a meridional altitude at sea when the horizon is not visible - Hadley — An account of Mr. Thomas Godfrey's improvement of Davis's quadrant, transferred to the mariner's-bow - Logan — A description of a water-level to be fixed to Davis's quadrant, whereby an observation may be taken at sea in thick and hazy weather, without seeing the horizon - Leigh — A description of an astronomical mural quadrant freed from many of the inconveniences it has hitherto laboured under - Gersten — A recommendation of Hadley's quadrant for surveying, especially the surveying of harbours, together with a particular application of it in some cases of pilotage - Michell — A letter describing some additions and alterations made to Hadley's quadrant, to render it more serviceable at sea - Dollond — Remarks on the Hadley's quadrant, tending principally to remove the difficulties which have hitherto attended the use of the back-observation, and to obviate the errors that might arise from a want of parallelism in the two surfaces of the index glass - Maskelyne — See Level QUADRATRIX. The construction and properties of a new quadratrix to the hyperbola - Perks Quadratic. Universal solution of quadratic and biquadratic equations, viz. analytical, geometrical, and mechanic! (In general) A particular account of the origin of fountains, and to shew that the rain and snow waters are sufficient to make fountains run perpetually — Anon. — An attempt to account for the rising and falling of the water of some ponds near the sea, or ebbing or flowing rivers; where the water is lowest in the pond, at the time of high water in the sea or river; and the water is the highest in the pond, at the time of low water in the sea or river; as also for the increasing or decreasing of the water of such pools or brooks as are highest in the dry seasons, and lowest in the rainy seasons; with an experiment to illustrate the solution of the phenomena — Desaguliers — An account of the use of furze in fencing the banks of rivers — Wark — Treatise on rivers and canals — Mann Rivers (Particular) Relation of the effects of a violent storm at Acomack in America, Oct. 19, 1693, on the rivers of that country Scarburgi — A relation of the bad condition of the mountain about the Tungarouse and Batavian rivers, having their source from thence, occasioned by the earthquake between the 4th and 5th of Jan. 1699, drawn up from the account given by Tommagam Porbo-Nata (who had been there) Anon. — Part of a letter concerning the stocking the river Mene with oysters — Rowland — An account of the river Niagara, taken at Albany, Oct. 10, 1721 — Baraffar — Account of the rise of some of the most considerable rivers of Europe — Scheuchzer — An account of the sinking of a river near Pontypool, in Monmouthshire, Jan. 1, 1756 — Matthews Rizzetti. The whole process used in France for making sea-salt by the sun Some enquiries and suggestions concerning salt for domestic uses; and concerning sheep, to preserve them, and to improve the race of sheep for hardness, and for the finest drapery A continuation of the discourse concerning vitriol, shewing, that vitriol is usually pro- duced by sulphur, acting on, and coagulating with a metal; and then making out, that allum is likewise the result of the said sulphur; as also evincing that vitriol, sulphur, and al- lum, do agree in the saline principles; and, lastly, declaring the nature of the salt in brimstone, and whence it is derived Microscopical observations of the figure of sugar and salt, and the probable cause of the differ- ence of their taste An extract of a letter concerning the salts of wine and vinegar An abstract of a letter concerning the various figures of the salts contained in several sub- stances | Salt | Microscopic observations on the figures of several salt particles, &c. | |------|---------------------------------------------------------------------| | | Letter concerning the figures of the salts of crystal | | | An extract of a letter containing microscopical observations on the salts of pearls, oyster-shells, &c. | | Salts (Chemistry.) | An account of an odd salt extracted out of a metallic substance | | | The principles and causes of the volatilization of salt of tartar, and other fixed salts | | | A way of extracting a volatile salt and spirit out of vegetables; where the water is lowest in the pond at the time of high water in the sea or river, and the water is highest in the pond at the time of low water in the sea or river; as also for the increasing or decreasing of the water of such pools or brooks as are highest in the dry seasons, and lowest in the rainy seasons; With other enquiries touching the sea. Observations about load-stones and sea-compasses. Answer to some magnetical enquiries proposed in the above observations. An account of a machine for measuring any depth at the sea with great expedition and certainty. A proposal of a method for finding the longitude at sea, within a degree, or twenty leagues; with an account of the progress he hath made therein, by a continued series of accurate observations of the moon. Description of the Spanish Sembrador or new engine for ploughing, and equal sowing all sorts of grain, and harrowing at once, by which a great quantity of seed-corn is saved, and a rich increase yearly gained. An account of a negro-boy that is dappled in several parts of his body with white spots Byrd — See Jupiter, Sun SPOUT. Letter concerning a spout of water that happened at Topsham, on the river between the sea and Exeter Mayne — An account of a water-spout observed in the Downs Gordon — Letter concerning some water-spouts he observed in the Mediterranean Stuart — Letter concerning a water-spout observed by him in Yorkshire De la Pryme — Letter concerning a spout lately observed by him at Hatfield De la Pryme — Part of a letter, giving a relation of a wonderful fall of water from a spout upon the Moors in Lancashire Richardson — The description of a water-spout Harris — An extraordinary meteor seen in the county of Rutland, resembling a water-spout Barker — An account of a water-spout raised off the land in Deeping-Fen, Lincolnshire Ray SPRING. An account of an ebbing and flowing spring in Westphalia, together with an information touching salt-springs, and the straining of salt-water Anon. — Of a remarkable spring about Paderborn, in Germany Anon. — Of some other not common springs at Basil, and in Alsatia Anon. — An account of a medical spring in Dorsetshire Highmore — Reflections relating to mineral springs considered, in vol. iv. 1050, with an account of some such springs Springs in England and other places, specifying how terrestrial steams may be the generative cause of minerals and metals, and of all the peculiarities of springs. **Springs.** Advertisements relating to springs, water, &c. An account of a medicinal spring on the banks or the river Wear, or Ware, in the bishoprick of Durham. An account of the circulation of the watry vapours of the sea, and of the cause of springs. Letter concerning a medicated spring in Glamorganshire. Conjectures upon the nature of intermitting and reciprocating springs. An account of a new purging spring discovered at Dulwich, in Surrey. Experiments by way of analysis upon the water of the Dead Sea, upon the hot springs near Tiberiades, and upon Hammon Pharoah water. Letter concerning the actions of springs. See Mineral Springs in their Places. **Square.** The method of squaring any kinds of curves, or reducing them to more simple ones. **Squilla Aquae Dulcis.** Part of a letter concerning the squilla aquae dulcis. **Squinting.** A new case in squinting. **Squirrel.** A letter containing some remarks relating to Mr. Ray's description of the flying squirrel of America. **Stag.** Extract of a letter concerning an extraordinary large horn, of the stag kind, taken out of the sea on the coast of Lancashire. A letter containing the description of a sort of stag in Virginia. **Stake.** An extraordinary cure of a horse that was staked into his stomach. **Stalactites.** Account of a beautiful stalactites, now in the Museum of the Royal Society. **Stamp.** The description of an antique metal stamp in the collection of the Duke of Richmond. being one of the instances how near the Romans had arrived to the art of printing; with some remarks **Stars, Fixed.** Some more accurate observations about Jupiter's transits near fixed stars, useful for determining the inclination of that planet to the ecliptic New observations made after a new and accurate way, of the farthest elongations of the Medicean stars from the center of Jupiter; together with some uncommon ones concerning the diameters of the planets, and their distances from fixed stars, as also of the parallax of Mars, in opposition to the sun and in perigee, &c. The longitudes, latitudes, right ascensions, and declinations of the chiefest fixed stars according to the observations of the ancients A proposal concerning the parallax of the fixed stars, in reference to the earth's annual orb Concerning the distance of the fixed stars An instrument for seeing the sun, moon, or stars, pass the meridian of any place; useful for setting watches in all parts of the world with the greatest exactness, to correct sun-dials, to assist in the discovery of the longitude of places An account of several nebulae or lucid spots, like clouds, lately discovered in the fixed stars by help of the telescope Considerations on the change of the latitude of some of the principal fixed stars Of the infinity of the sphere of fixed stars Of the number, order, and light of the fixed stars A letter giving an account of a new discovered motion of the fixed stars Observations of the appearances among the fixed stars, called Nebulous stars, owing to the motion of the earth, and the motion of light compounded together The description and use of an apparatus added as an improvement to Davis's quadrant, con- listing of a mercurial level, for taking the co-altitude of sun or star at sea, without the usual assistance of the sensible horizon, which frequently is obscured Stars. (Fixed) A letter concerning an apparent motion observed in some of the fixed stars, owing to a nutation of the earth's axis Remarks on the mutations of the stars A letter containing the results of observations of the distance of the moon from the sun and fixed stars, made in a voyage from England to the island of St Helena, in order to determine the longitude of the ship from time to time, together with the whole process of computation used on the occasion Concise rules for computing the effects of refraction and parallax in varying the apparent distance of the moon from the sun or a star; also an easy rule of approximation for computing the distance of the moon from a star, the longitude and latitude of both being given; with demonstrations of the same An inquiry into the probable parallax and magnitude of the fixed stars, from the quantity of light which they afford us, and the particular circumstances of their situation Stars. Jan 3, 1765 — Observations upon a thunder storm — A letter describing a remarkable storm at Buckland Brewer, Devon, March 2, 1769 — An account of a remarkable thunder storm, Feb. 18, 1770, at St. Keverne, in Cornwall — Extract of a letter concerning a thunder and lightning storm, by which Mr. Heartly, of Harrowgate, was killed, Sept. 29, 1772 — Account of the effects of a thunder storm on the 15th of March, 1733, upon the house of Lord Tylney, at Naples — See *Hail*, *Lightning*, *Rain*, *Thunder* **STOVE.** An account of a lately invented stove for preserving plants in the greenhouse in winter, published at the end of the *Calendarium Hortense* — The manner in which the Chinese heat their rooms — An account of the kang, or Chinese stove **STRAIGHT’S-MOUTH.** A conjecture about an under current at the Straight’s-Mouth — Of the currents at the Straight’s Mouth **STRALSUND.** See *Thunac* **STRATA.** An account of the strata met with in digging for marle, and of horns found under ground in Ireland — A description of a petrified stratum formed from the waters of Matlock, Derbyshire **STRAWBERRIES.** Microscopical observations on the seeds of figs, strawberries, &c. **STRING.** Concerning the motion of stretched string **STUPEFACTION.** An account of a case of a young man stupified by the smoke of sea-coal **STYLE.** Letter judging of the age of the MSS of learned authors, painters, musicians, &c. by the STYLE. Gamel Petiver Substances. An account of two uncommon mineral substances in some coal and iron mines in England Jeffop SUBSTANCES. Concerning the various figures of the salts contained in the several substances Leeuwenhoek — Letter concerning a substance coughed up resembling the veils of the lungs Buffier — Cafe of a gentlewoman who voided with her urine hairy crustaceous substances; with Sir H. Sloane's answer, containing several observations of extraordinary substances voided by the urinary passages Powel and Sloane — Cafe of hair voided by urine Knight — A summary of some late observations upon the generation, composition and decomposition of animal and vegetable substances Needham — An account of a curious fleshy coral-like substance, with some observations on it by Mr. John Ellis Schloesser — A description of three substances mentioned by the Arabian physicians, in a paper sent from Aleppo, and translated from the Arabian by J. Channing — A short narrative of the structure and effect of parabolick burning speculums, made by the late Mr. Hoeven, of Dresden; and an account of experiments made with them on the fusion of different substances Wolfe — Experiments on ignited bodies Reubuck — Experiments on ignited substances Whitehurst — Experiments on some mineral substances Wolfe SUBTERRANEUS FIRE. Bishop of Cork SUGAR. Microscopical observations on the figure of sugar and salt, and the probable cause of the difference of their taste Leeuwenhoek SUGAR. An account of a sort of sugar made of the juice of maple in Canada - Anon. Microscopical observations on the particles of crystallized sugar - Leeuw Niek Observations upon the nature and properties of sugar - Slare An account of the method of making sugar from the juice of the maple-tree in New England - Dudley Account of the method of cultivating the sugar cane - Cazaux Knowledge necessary to judge of any kind of sugar - Mills SULPHUR. A description of a Swedish stone which affords sulphur, vitriol, allum, and minium - Talbot Some observations and experiments about vitriol, tending to find out the nature of that substance, and to give further light in the inquiry after the principles and properties of other minerals - Anon. A continuation of a discourse concerning vitriol, shewing, that vitriol is usually produced by sulphur, acting on, and coagulating with, a metal; and then making out, that allum is likewise the result of the said sulphur; as also evincing, that vitriol, sulphur, and allum, do agree in the saline principle; and lastly declaring the nature of the salt in brimstone, and whence it is derived - Anon. Two letters giving an account of a red colour produced by mixture of a sulphureous spirit with a volatile alkali - Gibbens A relation of a stone quarry at Pyrmont, from which a sulphurous smoke issues like that from the cave at Naples, called the Grotto of Dogs, described by Misson, and others - Srip A letter concerning a hall of sulphur supposed to be generated in the air - Cook An account of two caves, one of ice, the other throwing out noxious exhalations - Belius An easy method of procuring the volatile acid of sulphur - Seibl Thoughts on the different impregnations of mineral waters; more particularly concerning the existence of sulphur in some of them - Rust An account of the sulphureous mineral waters - Ooo of Castle-Leod and Fairburn, in the county of Ross, and of the salt purging waters of Pitkeathly, in the county of Perth, in Scotland. **Summer.** An inquiry into the causes of a dry and wet summer **Sun.** (In general) A method for finding the number of the Julian period for any year assigned, the number of the cycle of the sun, the cycle of the moon, and of the indications for the same year, being given together, with a demonstration of that method A certain phenomenon seen in Prussia, about the sun, a little before his setting, and the moon's conjunction, and the sun's eclipse, (which was not seen by him) A letter for correcting the hitherto assigned motions of the sun Concerning the apparent magnitude of the sun and moon, or the apparent distance of two stars, when nigh the horizon, and when higher elevated The sentiments of Dr. Wallis on the aforesaid appearances A discourse concerning a method of discovering the true moment of the sun's ingress into the tropical signs Observations on the meridian height of the sun, to investigate the elevation of the pole at Lisbon An observation of an uncommon gleam of light proceeding from the sun Part of a letter concerning the gradual approach of the earth to the sun **Sun.** (Attraction of the) An estimate of the quantity of vapour raised out of the sea by the warmth of the sun, derived from an experiment shewn before the Royal Society A resolution of a general proposition for determining the hourly alteration of the position of the terrestrial equator, from the attraction of the sun and moon, with some remarks on the solutions given by other authors to that difficult and important problem On the precession of the equinoxes produced by the sun's attraction **Sun.** (Conjunction with) An astronomical disserta- tion on the visible conjunction of the inferior planets with the sun — Haller Sun. (Eclipses of the sun) Observations of the eclipse of the sun June 22, 1666, at London — Willoughby, Pope, Hook, and Philips Madrid — Earl of Sandwicke Paris — Payen Calculation of the solar eclipse, July 2, 1666 — Hevelius The reasons why, in this eclipse, the diameter of the moon did increase about the end — Auxout Observations of the solar eclipse of the sun, June 1, 1676 — Smethwick Cayon Observations on the eclipse of the sun, June 23, 1675, at Dantzig — Hevelius Observations on the eclipse of the sun, June 11, 1676, in England — Flamstead, Townley, and Halton Paris — Cassini Dantzig — Hevelius An observation on the solar eclipse of June 11, 1676, at Avignon — Gallet Observation on an eclipse of the sun at Greenwich, July 2, 1684 — Flamsteed Paris — Bullialdus and Cassini Calculation of the same eclipse, according to the Philolaic tables — Flamsteed Observations of the solar eclipse, July 2, 1685, at Oxford — Bernard Lisbon — Jacobs Dublin — Aub and Molyneux Tredagh — Ogburn Some observations on the eclipse of the sun May 1, 1687, made at various places and sent to the Royal Society — XVI 370 Observations on the eclipse of the sun, July 12, 1684, at Bologna — Guilelmini Observations on the eclipse of the sun, Sept. 13, 1699, at Oxford — Gregory Of the eclipse of the sun, Sept. 13, 1699, at Nuremberg — Wurzelbaur Sun (Eclipses.) At the North Cape — At Hawkhill — Bayly — At Ki-knewton — Alemore and Luid — Observations on the eclipse of the sun made at the island of Hammerfest, for the Royal Society — Bryce — Observations of a solar eclipse, June 4, 1769, at Aithorpe, near Leeds, Yorkshire — Dixon — Observations on the eclipse of the sun made at Gibraltar — Jardine — Observations on the eclipse of the sun, June 4, 1769, in the morning — Smeaton — Extract of a letter inclosing some account of a solar eclipse observed at the island of Otaheite, by Captain Wallis, July 25, 1767 — Wallis — Observations on the solar eclipse which happened June 24, 1778 — Wale — An eclipse of the sun, June 24, 1778, observed at Leicester — Ludlam — Observations on the eclipse of the sun taken the 24th of June, 1778, on board the Espagne, in the passage from the Azores — Uliao — Vide Halo, Parelia SUN. (Heat of the) A discourse concerning the proportional heat of the sun in all latitudes, with the method of collecting the same — Halley — Account of an experiment made with a thermometer, whose bulb was painted black, and exposed to the direct rays of the sun — Richard Watson SUN. (Horizontal) Some thoughts concerning the sun and moon, when near the horizon, appearing larger than when nearer the zenith — Logan The description and use of an apparatus, added as an improvement to Davis's quadrant, consisting of a mercurial level, for taking the altitude of sun or star at sea, without the usual assistance of the sensible horizon, which is often obscured — Leigh An attempt to assign the cause why the sun and moon appear to the naked eye larger when they are near the horizon; with an account of several natural phenomena, relative to this subject — Dun SUN (As applied for determining the longitude.) An instrument for seeing the sun, moon, or stars pass the meridian of any place, useful for setting watches in all parts of the world with the greatest exactness, to correct sun-dials, to assist in the discovery of the longitudes of places. Sun (As applied for determining the longitude.) A letter containing the results of observations of the distance of the moon from the sun and fixed stars, made in a voyage from England to the island of St. Helena, in order to determine the longitude of the ship from time to time; together with the whole process of computation used on this occasion. Track of his Majesty's armed brig Lion, from England to Davis's Streights, and Labrador, with observations for determining the longitude by sun and moon, and error of common reckoning; also the variation of the compass and dip of the needle, as observed during the said voyage in 1776. Sun. (parallax) Of the correspondence to be procured for finding out the true distance of the sun and moon from the earth, by the parallax, observed under (or near) the same meridian. A particular method by which the parallax of the sun, or its distance from the earth, may be ascertained by the assistance of the transit of Venus over the sun. An account of the sun's distance from the earth deduced from Mr. Short's observations relating to the horizontal parallax of the sun. Second paper concerning the parallax of the sun determined from the observations of the late transit of Venus. A discourse on the parallax of the sun. Concise rules for computing the effects of refraction and parallax in varying the apparent distance of the moon from the sun or a star; also an easy rule of approximation for computing the distance of the moon from a star, the longitudes and latitudes of both being given, with demonstrations of the same. Supplement to Mr. Pingré's memoir on the parallax of the sun; deduced from his observations on the transit of Venus, vol. LII, p. 371. SUN Sun (Parallax.) An essay on the connection between the parallaxes of the sun and moon, their densities, and their disturbing forces on the ocean. Murdock A determination of the solar parallax attempted, by a peculiar method, from the observations of the last transit of Venus, in a letter to James Short. Planman The quantity of the sun's parallax as deduced from the transit of Venus, June 3, 1769. Hornby A deduction of the sun's parallax from the comparison of the several observations of the late transit of Venus, made in Europe, with those made in George island in the South Seas, by Mr. Lexell. Euler Sun (Spots in the) Accounts of some spots of the sun, observed at Paris, Aug. 1671. Cassini New observations of spots in the sun, made at Paris, Aug. 11, 12, and 13, 1671. Derham Observations made on the spots on the body of the sun in the months of May, June, and July, 1704. Stanman Observations upon the spots that have been upon the sun from the year 1703 to 1711; with a letter of Mr. Crabtree in the year 1640 upon the same subject. Derham Further account. PP. Sun. Tangier in 1673 **TANNING.** An improved method of tanning leather **TAPESTRY.** An account of weaving tapestry in the same manner as brocades **TAPPING.** A remarkable case of a gentlewoman who died of an hydrops ovarii, in the 33rd year of her age, after having been tapped 57 times The case of Mr. Cox, surgeon at Peterborough, who fell into a pestilential fever upon tapping a corpse dead of an hydrophy Aficites, cured by An improvement on the practice of tapping, whereby that operation, instead of a relief for symptoms, becomes an absolute cure for an aiicites, exemplified in the case of Jane Roman A method of conveying liquors into the abdomen during the operation of tapping See *Dropfy* **TAR.** An account of making pitch, tar, and oil, out of a blackish stone in Shropshire The way of making pitch, tar, rosin and turpentine, near Marseille **TARANTULA.** An inquiry concerning tarantula's Observations made of persons pretending to be stung with tarantula's Some account of the tarantula **TARTARY.** A voyage of the Emperor of China into Eastern Tartary, 1682 A voyage of the Emperor of China into the Western Tartary, 1683 An explanation necessary to justify the geography supposed in these letters An account of a large and curious map of the Great Tartary **TAUSE.** Microscopical observations about the texture of the blood, the sap of some plants, the figure of sugar and salt, and the probable cause of the difference of their tastes. **Taste.** Letter concerning the different tastes of waters - Observations on the class of sweet tastes, made by comparing the tastes of sweet plants, with Mr. Lister's chymical analysis of them, in his treatise of sugars. - An account of some trials to cure the ill taste of milk, which is occasioned by the food of cows, either from turnips, cabbage, or autumnal leaves, &c., also too sweetening drinking water. **Taurus.** An account of an occultation of the star ξ Tauri, by the moon, observed at Leicester - Occultation of α or γ Tauri and other stars by the moon **Tea.** An account of a voyage to Chusan, in China, with a description of the island, of the several sorts of tea, of the fishing, agriculture of the Chinese, &c., with several observations not hitherto taken notice of **Tears.** Microscopical observations concerning sweat, fat, tears, &c. **Teeth.** Two cases of persons cutting teeth in their old age - Microscopical observations of the structure of teeth, and other bones - Microscopical observations about animals in the scurf of the teeth, the substance called worms in the nose, &c. - Concerning animalcules found in teeth - Of a venomous scratch with the tooth of a porpois, its symptoms, and cure - Observations on teeth - Letter concerning worms pretended to be taken from the teeth - Part of a letter concerning a person who had a new set of teeth after 80 years of age; with some observations upon the virtues and properties of sugar - A letter giving an account of some Judgment touching the apertures of object glasses, and their proportions, in respect to the several lengths of telescopes, together with a table thereof Auzout Of M. Hevelius's promise of imparting to the world his invention of making optick glasses; and of the hopes given by Mr. Hugens, of Zulichem, to perform something of the like nature; as also of the expectations conceived of some ingenious persons in England to improve telescopes Hevelius, Hugens, and Du Sons Instance to Mr. Hook, for communicating a contrivance of making, with a glass of a sphere of 20 or 40 feet diameter, a telescope, drawing several hundred feet, and of his offer of recompensing that secret with another teaching to measure, with a telescope, the distances of objects from the earth Auzout A method by which a glass of a small plano-convex sphere, may be made to refract the rays of light to a focus of a far greater distance than is usual Hook Method of polishing telescopic glasses by a turn-lathe, and the making of an extraordinary burning glass at Milan Anon. An account of a new catadioptrical telescope invented by Mr. Newton Newton Further suggestions about his reflecting tele- Q q q scope; together with his table of apertures and charges for the several lengths of that instrument. Answer to some objections made by an ingenious French philosopher, to the new reflecting telescope. Some considerations upon part of a letter of M. de Berce, concerning the catadioptrical telescope, pretended to be improved and refined by M. Cassigrain. Telescopes. The effects of the different refractions of the rays in telecopical glasses. Hopes of perfecting telescopes by reflections rather than refractions. The use of telescopic sights in astronomical observations. A sure and easy way to make all sorts of great telecopical glasses, with a generous offer of furnishing industrious astronomers with them. Letter about the price of his telescopes. The description of an aerial telescope. A dioptrick problem, why four convex-glasses in a telescope shew objects erect. Extracts from Mr. Gafroigne's and Mr. Crabtree's letters, proving Mr. Gafcoigne to have been the inventor of the telecopick sights of mathematical instruments, and not the French. A way for myopes to use telescopes without eye glasses, an object glass becoming as useful to them, and sometimes more, than a combination of glasses. Some remarks upon the method of observing the differences of right ascension and declination, by crofs hairs in a telescope. An account of a catadioptrick telescope made by John Hadley, Esq. with the description of a machine, contrived by him, for applying it to use. A letter concerning observations made with Mr. Hadley's reflecting telescope. Observations on the satellites of Jupiter and Saturn, made with the same telescope. A new method of improving and perfecting catadioptrical telescopes by forming the speculums of glass instead of metal. **TELESCOPES.** The description and uses of an equatorial telescope - Letter concerning an improvement of refracting telescopes by increasing the number of eyeglasses to enlarge the field of view - Letter relating to a theorem of Mr. Euler to correct the aberrations in the object glasses of reflecting telescopes - An account of some new experiments concerning the different refrangibility of light by water, and different kinds of glass; and of a method thence deduced, of correcting the errors arising from the different refrangibility of light in the object-glasses of reflecting telescopes - An account of an improvement made by Mr. Dollond in his new telescopes, by composing his object-glasses of two convex lenses of crown glass, and one concave lens of white flint - A method of working the object glasses of reflecting telescopes truly spherical - Description and use of a new constructed equatorial telescope, or portable observatory - An improvement proposed in the cross wires of telescopes - Directions for making the best composition for the metals of reflecting telescopes; together with a description of the process for grinding, polishing, and giving the great speculum the true parabolic curve - Account of an iconantidiptic telescope **TEMPERATURE OF THE EARTH.** Advertisements of the warm and fertilizing temperature of the earth, stones, rocks, &c. **TEMPERS.** An essay tending to make a probable conjecture of tempers by the modulations of the voice in ordinary discourse **TEMPESTS.** Advertisements of black winds, tempests, &c. **TEMPLE.** An explanation of the figures of a Pagan temple, and unknown characters at Cannara, in Salset - Part of a letter concerning the remains of an ancient temple in Ireland, and of a stone hatchet of the antient Irish **TENDON.** An account of stitching the great tendon between the calf of the leg and heel, with its union and cure, after an entire division of it, with remarks TENDON. An account of the case of the first joint of the thumb torn off, with the flexor tendon in its whole extent torn out Cafe of William Carey, aged 19, whose tendons and muscles were turned into bones Further account TENERIFFE. An account of a journey from the port of Oratava, in the island of Teneriffe, to the top of the pike in that island, in Aug. 1715, with observations thereon by Observations made in going up the Pic of Teneriffe Some account of a salt found on the Pic of Teneriffe TERCERA. Part of a letter concerning a new Island lately raised out of the sea near Tercera TERNATA. An account of the upper part of the burning mountain in the isle of Ternata, according to the view taken thereof TERRELLA. A letter about the load-stone, where chiefly the suggestion of Gilbert, touching the circumvolution of a globous magnet, called terrella, and the variation of the variation is examined Tessellated Work. Part of a letter concerning an antient tessellated or Mosaick work at Leicester Tessera. A brief account of a Roman tessera Testicle. Testis examinatus, formerly printed at Florence, by Vauclius Dathirius Bonglarus; now reprinted, because the subject is under a severer examination among the curious anatomists both here, in France, and Holland Anatomical observations in the body of a woman about 50 years of age, who died hydropical in her left testicle An account of the forming of a foetus in the testicle Examination of the testicle of a rat, and the seed of muscles, oysters, &c. Testimony. A calculation upon the credibility of human testimony TETANUS. Observations upon the effects of electricity applied to a tetanus, or muscular rigidity of four months continuance W. Watson THALES. Letter concerning the year of the eclipse foretold by Thales — Cofard — An account of the eclipse predicted by Thales — Stukeley THERMOMETER. An account of several experiments made to examine the nature of the expansion and contraction of fluids by heat and cold, in order to ascertain the divisions of the thermometer, and to make that instrument in all places, without adjusting by a standard Halley — Observations on the thermometer and magnetic needle, in his voyage to the Cape of Good Hope, 1700, Cunningham — Account of a new thermometer depending on the variation of the spring of the air by heat and cold — Geoffroy — An account of an experiment made to ascertain the proportion of the expansion of the liquor in the thermometer, with regard to the degrees of heat Taylor — A meteorological, barometrical, thermometrical, epidemical, and magnetical diary, kept at Utrecht, 1729 Van Musschenbroek 1730 and 1731 Van Musschenbroek — Extract of a letter concerning the construction of a quicksilver thermometer, and his observations on the eclipses of Jupiter's satellites, in the years 1731 and 1732 Delisle — Description of the thermometer Pickering — A letter concerning the difference of the degrees of cold, marked by a thermometer kept within doors, or without in the open air, Dec. 1, 2, 3, 1747 Miles — A discourse concerning the usefulness of thermometers in chymical experiments, and concerning the principles on which the thermometers now in use have been constructed; together with the description and uses of a metallic thermometer, newly invented C. Mortimer — A letter concerning a metallic thermometer, in the Museum of the Gentlemens' Society, at Spalding Johnson — A letter concerning thermometers, and some observations observations of the weather A letter of the near agreement of thermometers in London and at Tooting Thermometrical observations made by M. Demioff, at Sokolovsky, on the borders of Siberia, lat. 59°, in 1751, by a thermometer adapted to M. de L'isle's case, which, in this ext. &c., are reduced, likewise to those of Fahrenheit, and M. Raymurt E. of Macclesfield A comparison of different thermometrical observations in Siberia An account of the state of the thermometers, on the 8th and 9th of February, 1755 A description of the state of the thermometer at the Haute, Jan 9, 1757 A description of some thermometers for particular uses Thermometrical account of the weather in Maryand for four years, 1753 to 1757 A description of a metallic thermometer A description of a new thermometer and barometer Thermometrical observations at Derby Observations on the barometer, thermometer, and r. i., at Plymouth, 1767 Account of an experiment made with a thermometer, whose bulb was painted black, and exposed to the direct rays of the sun Extract of a register of the barometer, thermometer, and rain, at Lyndon, in Rutland, 1772 thermometrical observations at Allahabad, in the East Indies, in latitude 25° 30' N. during the year 1767, and also during a voyage from Madras to England, in the year 1774 **THE** **THERMOMETER.** Extract of a register of the barometer, thermometer, and rain, at Lyndon, in Rutland, 1775 Extract of a register of the barometer, thermometer, and rain, at Lyndon in Rutland, 1776 The report of the Committee appointed by the Royal Society to consider of the best method of adjusting the fixed points of thermometers, and of the precautions necessary to be used in making experiments with those observations concerning the baroscope and thermoscope **THIBET.** An account of the kingdom of Thibet **THIGH.** A letter concerning a woman of 62 years of age, that lost her leg, and greatest part of her thigh, by a gangrene Observations on a fracture in the upper part of the thigh bone The case of Grace Lowdell, aged about 60 years, who had an extraordinary tumour on her thigh The description and draught of a machine for reducing the fracture of the thigh An account of a large piece of the thigh-bone which was taken out, and its place supplied by a callus **THIGH.** See *Aneurism, Luxation* Pecquet of a communication between the ductus thoracicus and the vena cava THORACIC DUCT. Account of an ossification of the thoracic duct CHESTON THORAX. An account of what happened on syringing warm water into the thorax of a bitch MUSGRAVE — Letter concerning a child who had its intestines, mesentery, &c. in the cavity of the thorax HOLS — An account of a praeter-natural bony substance found in the cavity of the thorax RUTTY THROAT. Some observations concerning the virtue of the jelly of the black currants, in curing inflammations in the throat BAKER — Some account of a sheep having a monstrous horn growing from his throat PARSONS — An account of the case of a man who died of the effects of the fire at Eddystone light-house by melted lead running down his throat SPRY — Another account HUXHAM THUMB. An account of the case of the first joint of the thumb torn off, with the flexor tendon in its whole extent torn out HOME THUNDER. A relation of an accident by thunder and lightning at Oxford, May 10, 1666 WALIS — A relation of the sad effects of thunder and lightning in Hampshire, Jan. 24, 1665-6 NEALE — Odd effects of a dreadful thunder-clap at Stralsund, in Pomerania, June 1670 ANON. — An odd effect of thunder and lightning upon wheat and rye in the granaries at Dantzig KIRKBY — Letter containing particulars of a philosophical nature viz. a narrative of the strange effects of thunder upon a magnetic card ANON. — Observation concerning thunder and lightning being from the pyrites LISTER — A relation of the effect of a thunder clap on the compass of a ship on the coast of New-England, July 24, 1681 OLDENBURG — A letter concerning former relations SIR R. Some remarkable effects of a great storm of thunder and lightning at Portsmouth, Oct. 23, 1685 The relation of a storm of thunder, lightning, and hail, at Oundle, in Northamptonshire An account of the effects of a very extraordinary thunder near Aberdeen in Scotland Letter concerning the generation of hail, of thunder, and lightning, and the effects thereof Some additions to his letter about thunder and lightning A true and exact relation of the dismal and surprising effects of a terrible and unusual clap of thunder and lightning that fell upon the Trumbull galley, Nov. 26, 1696 Letter concerning the effects of thunder and lightning at Everdon, in Northamptonshire, (wherein divers persons were killed) July 27, 1691 An account of a young man slain with thunder and lightning, Dec 22, 1698 Of an accident by thunder and lightning, at Leeds, April 27, 1700 A relation of the strange effects of thunder and lightning which happened in the county of Down, in Ireland, Aug. 9, 1707 Part of a letter giving an account of a storm of thunder and lightning that happened at Ipswich, July 16, 1708 The effects of the above storm at Colchester Part of a letter concerning a storm of thunder, and lightning, and rain, at Leeds, in Yorkshire, August 5, 1701 A letter giving an account of a storm of thunder, and lightning, which happened near Leeds, in Yorkshire A relation of the effects of a storm of thunder and lightning at Sampford Courtney, in Devonshire, on Oct. 7, 1711 An account of what happened from thunder in Carmarthenshire, Dec 6, 1729 An extract of a letter concerning the crooked and angular darts of lightning in thunder storms THUNDER. An account of the tides in the Adriatic Timber. Instances shewing the correspondence of the pith and timber, with the seed of the plant; as also of the bark, or sap in the bark, with the pulp of the fruit, or some encompassing coat or cod containing the seed. A discourse concerning the most reasonable time of felling of timber; written by the advice of S. Pepys. Letter concerning the difference of timber growing in different countries, and felled at different seasons of the year. Time. Letter concerning a movement that measures time after a particular manner, with an account of the reasons of the said motion. A letter wherein he asserts his right to the curious and useful invention of making clocks to keep time with the sun's apparent motion. Some remarks upon the equation of time, and the manner of computing it. Short and easy methods for finding the quantity of time contained in any given number of mean lunations, and the number of new lunations in any given quantity of time. A determination of the exact moments of time when the planet Venus was at external and internal contact with the sun's limb in the transits, of June 6, 1761, and June 3, 1769. A new method of finding time by equal altitudes. Tin. An account of some mineral observations touching the mines of Cornwall and Devon; wherein is described the art of training a load, the art and manner of digging the ore, and the way of dressing and blowing tin. A relation of the tin-mines, and working of tin in the county of Cornwall. The method of making tin plates, extracted from the memoirs of the Academy of Sciences for 1725. Two extraordinary cases, one of a large stone in the urethra, occasioned by a venereal infection, the other of a child born with a remarkable tumour on the loins An account of a large glandular tumour in the pelvis; and of the pernicious effects of crude mercury given inwardly to the patient An account of an extraordinary tumour in the knee of a person whose leg was taken off The case of Grace Lowdell, aged about 60 years, who had an extraordinary tumour on her thigh An account of tumours which rendered the bones soft A letter concerning a child born with an extraordinary tumour near the anus, containing some rudiments of an embryo in it A letter containing the description of a new invented instrument for the extirpation of tumours out of the reach of the surgeon's fingers The case of an extraordinary tumour growing on the inside of the bladder successfully extirpated An account of some extraordinary tumours upon the head of a labouring man Case of a young lady who drank sea water for an inflammation and tumour in the upper lip Account of an extraordinary steatomatous tumour, in the abdomen of a woman Tumuli. Of the mineral of Liege, yielding both brimstone and vitriol, and the way of extracting them out of it used at Liege — Account of a pond, in Somersetshire, to which pigeons resort but cattle will not drink at it Further account of the (pond) vitriolate water, with some particulars touching water — A description of a Swedish stone, which affords sulphur, vitriol, allum, and minium — Some observations and experiments about vitriol, tending to prove the nature of that substance, and to give further light in the inquiry after the principles and properties of other minerals — A continuation of the discourse concerning vitriol, shewing, that vitriol is usually produced by sulphur, acting on, and coagulating with a metal; and then making out, that allum is likewise the result of the said sulphur; as also VITRUM ANTIMONII CERATUM. W A T Water. (Gravity) An account of some experiments in relation to the weight of common water under different circumstances. — An experiment touching the weighing of bodies of the same species, but very unequal surfaces in common water, being of an equal weight in common air. — The specific gravity of several metallic cubes, in comparison with their like bulks of water. — A caution to be used in examining the specific gravity of solids by weighing them in water. — A course of experiments to ascertain the specific buoyancy of cork in different waters, the respective weights and buoyancy of salt water, and fresh water, and for determining the exact weight of human and other bodies in fluids. Water. (Hydraulics) A way of producing wind by the fall of water. — Undertaking for raising of water. — A new way of raising water. — Letter concerning Dr. Papin's way of raising water. — Letter concerning Dr. Papin's new water engine. — A full description, with the use, of a new contrivance for raising water. — Answer to several objections made by Mr. Nuis against his engine for raising water by the rarefaction of the air. — An account of the motion of running water. — A description of an engine to raise water by help of quicksilver, invented by Haskins, and improved by Desaguliers. — A defense of the dissertation on the motion of running water against the animadversions of P. A. Michelotti. — An account of several experiments concerning the running of water in pipes, as it is retarded by friction and intermixed air, with a description of a new machine, whereby pipes may be cleared of air, as the water runs along, without stand-pipes, or the help of any hand. extraordinary lake in Lord Lovat's lands in Scotland, of Lake Neus, and of a petrifying rivulet. — Makenzy — Advertisements concerning black-winds and tempests. — Beal — The breath of the sea plants probably the mate- W I N rial cause of the trade or tropick winds Wind. A letter concerning the use which may be made of the following history of the weather Observations of the wind, weather, and height of Mercury in the barometer, at Oxford Extract of a letter concerning the causes of several winds An historical account of the trade winds, and monsoons, observable in the seas between and near the tropicks, with an attempt to assign the physical cause of the said winds Part of a letter accompanying his observations of the height of the Mercury in the barometer, rains, winds, &c. for the year 1698 Observations of the weather made in a voyage to China, 1700 A register of the wind and weather at China, with the observations of the mercurial barometer at Chusan from Nov. 1700, to Jan. 1702 A prospect of the weather, winds, and height of the Mercury in the barometer on the first day of the month, and of the whole rain in every month in 1703, and beginning of 1704, at Townley in Lancashire And at Upminster Tables of the barometrical altitudes at Zurich in Switzerland, in the year 1708, by Scheuhzer, and at Upminster in England, by Derham, as also the rain at Pisa in Italy in 1707, and 1708, by Tilli, and at Zurich in 1708, and at Upminster in all that time: with remarks on the same table, as also on the winds, heats, and cold, and divers other matters occurring in those three different parts of Europe An account of an extraordinary stream of wind which shot through part of the parishes of Termonomungam and Urney, in the county of Tyrone, Oct. 11, 1752 Letters concerning the cause of the ascent of vapour and exhalation, and those of winds; and of the general phenomena of the weather and barometer WIN WOL Wind. An experimental enquiry concerning the natural powers of water and wind to turn mills and other machines depending on a circular motion. — A letter containing a new manner of measuring the velocity of wind. — Observations on the state of air, winds, weather, &c., made at Prince of Wales's Fort on the north-west coast of Hudson's Bay in 1768, and 1769. Wind Gage. Description and use of a portable wind gage. Wind Machines. Observations on Mr. Sutton's invention to extract foul and flinking air out of ships, with critical remarks upon the use of wind sails. — Of the degrees and quantities of wind requisite to move the heavier kinds of wind machines. Windpipe. An account of gases found in the wind pipes of some animals. — An account of a polypus coughed up by the windpipe. — An account of some peculiar advantages in the structure of the aspera arteria, or windpipes of several birds, and in the land testicle. Windows. A dissertation on the antiquity of glass in windows. — See Glass. Windsor Loam. A letter concerning Windsor loam. Wine. Of the globules in the blood and in the dress of wine. — An account of the Tokay and other wines in Hungary. Winter. Account of damage done in his garden by the preceding winter. — An account of the lately invented stove for preserving plants in the greenhouse in winter. Wire. An account of the effect of electricity in shortening of wires. Wolf. The history of the generations of an insect by him called the wolf; with some observations on insects bred in rain water, in apples, cheese, &c. Trans. Abridg. D. D. An experiment to examine what figure or celerity of motion begetteth or increaseth light and flame. I 126 — 639 Observations touching putrefaction — 320 — 149 Promiscuous observations made in Somersetshire (of places on moors parched up in the shape of trees, under which oak trees are found; of a pond to which pigeons resort, but cattle will not drink at it, and the method of taking eels in frothy weather) — 323 II 323, 423, 837 Further account of the pond, with some particulars touching waters — 359 — 332 Account of some sanative waters in Herefordshire I 358 Some proposals to try the effects of the pneumatick engine exhausted on plants, seeds, and the eggs of silk worms II 424 — 656 Communication about vegetation IIi 853 — 676 Instances shewing the correspondence of the pith and timber, with the seed of the plant, as also of the bark or sap in the bark, with the pulp of the fruit, or some encompassing coat or cod containing the seed IV 919 — 710 Observations concerning the baroscope and thermoscope — 1113 — 5, 32 Causes of mineral springs inquired, and the strange and secret changes of liquors examined VI 1131 — 712 Instances, hints, and applications relating to a main point solicited in the preface to this fourth volume, concerning the use may be made of vaults, deep wells and cold conservatories, to find out the cause, or to promote the generation of salt, minerals, metals, crystal, gems, stones of divers kinds, and helps to conserve long, or to hasten, putrefaction, fertility of any kind of land, &c. Beale, J. D. D. Reflections relating to medical springs; vol. IV. 1050, considered, with an account of some such springs in England and other places, specifying how terrestrial steams may be the generative cause of minerals and metals, and of all the peculiarities of springs Some considerations of what choice of apples for the delicacy of the liquor in peculiar seasons, and for easy and speedy propagation: pears for some lands proper, their choice for manifold uses, especially for pleasant, or for lathing liquor: and how to be planted and ordered to the best advantage Considerations on an apiary Some considerations on Mr. Reed's letter, shewing in what tenor the sap may be said to descend and to circulate in plants; and the graft to communicate with the stock On the best season for transplanting An account of a strange frost which hath done much hurt about Bristol Some inquiries and suggestions concerning salt for domestique uses; and concerning sheep, to preserve them, and to improve the race of sheep for hardiness, and for the finest drapery Advertisements occasioned by the remarks printed in vol. X, 305, upon frosts in some parts of Scotland, differing in their anniversary seasons and force, from our ordinary frosts in England; of black winds and tempests; of the warm and fertilizing temperature and steams of the earth, stones, rocks, springs, waters, (some, in some places, more than others, in other places) of petrifying and metallizing waters; with some hints for the horti-culture of Scotland Observation on the Vinetum Britannicum Two instances of something remarkable in shining flesh Agristic observations and advertisements Hortulan and rural advertisements Beard, R. the tempering of steel, and effervescence, accounted for by the same principle — A new trocart for the puncture in the hydrocephalus, and for other evacuations which are necessary to be made at different times — Observations on fungous excrescences of the bladder; a cutting forceps for extirpating these excrescences; and a canula for treating these diseases — Several cases of hernias and disorders of the urethra — Letter concerning the dissection of a rupture — An account of those malignant fevers, that raged at Rouen, at the end of the year 1753, and the beginning of 1754 — An account of the extraction of three inches and ten lines of the bone of the upper arm, which was followed by a regeneration of the bony matter; with a description of a machine made use of to keep the upper and lower pieces of the bone at their proper distances, during the time that the regeneration was taking place; place; and which may also be of service in fractures happening near the head of that bone. CAT, CLAUDE NIALE, M.D. An account of a monstrous human foetus, having neither head, heart, lungs, stomach, spleen, pancreas, liver, nor kidneys. An account of an hydro-enterocele appearing like a hydro-sarcocele, and ending in the death of the patient, in which the intestine had passed from the hernial sac, into that of the hydrocele, by which the strangulation was formed. SPENCER. of an agitation of the water at Durham. Nov. 1, 1755 COX, —— Surgeon. Case of a surgeon of Peterborough who fell into a pestilent fever upon tapping the corpse of a man lately dead of a dropsey COXE, DANIEL, M.D. A way of extracting a volatile salt and spirit out of vegetables — A discourse, denying the pre-existence of alcalizate or fixed salts in any subject, before it were exposed to the action of the fire; to which is added, a confirmation of an assertion, delivered in vol. IX. p. 4, viz. that alcalizate or fixed salts, extracted out of the ashes of vegetables, do not differ from each other; the same being affirmed of volatile salts and vinous spirits. — A continuation of a discourse begun in vol. IX. p. 150, touching the identity of all volatile salts and vinous spirits; together with the surprising experiments concerning vegetable salts perfectly resembling the shape of the plants whence they had been obtained. Experiments relating to the resistance of fluids — Remarks on some attempts made to obtain a perpetual motion — Improvement of Mr. Haskin's engine to raise water by help of quicksilver. — Account of an optical experiment made before the Royal Society — Experiments made to prove that the whole force of moving bodies is proportionable to their velocities — Animadversions upon some experiments relating to the force of moving bodies; with two new experiments on the same subject — An attempt to account for the rising and falling of the water of some ponds near the sea, or ebbing or flowing rivers; where the water is lowest in the pond at the time of high-water in the sea or river, and the water is the highest in the pond at the time of low-water in the sea or river; as also for the increasing or decreasing of the water of such pools or brooks as are highest in dry seasons, and lowest in the rainy seasons; with an experiment to illustrate the solution of the phenomena — A new contrivance for taking levels — A dissertation concerning the figure of the earth continued — An experiment to illustrate what has been said concerning the figure of the earth — Experiments concerning the cohesion of lead — Experiments concerning the running of water in pipes — Account of Mr. Hale's Vegetable Statics — An attempt made to shew how damps or foul air may be drawn out of any sort of mines, &c. by an engine — Account of a machine for measuring any depth at sea — Experiments made in August, 1728, before the Royal Society, upon occasion of Signor Rizzetti's opticks, with an account of that book — An attempt to solve the phenomenon of the rise of vapours, formation of clouds, and descent of rain XXXI 142 VI 299 — 214 — 323 XXXII 5 — 352 — 206 — 145 — 269 — 281 — 221, 285 XXXIII 132 VI 2 165 — 165 VI 271 — 201, VI 2 250 238, 277 VI 384 — 344 — 400 — 345 — 325 XXXIV 77 — 347 XXXV 323 VI 2 158 — 353 — 193 — 559 — 163 — 607 VI 110 XXXVI 6 VI 2 61 Desaguliers, J. D., A proposition on the balance, not taken notice of by mechanical writers, explained and confirmed Observations on the crane, with improvements on that machine Examination of a new-invented axis in peritrochoid, said to be void of friction An account of an experiment explaining a mechanical paradox, viz. that two bodies of equal weight, suspended on a certain sort of balance, do not lose their equilibrium, by being removed one farther from, the other nearer to, the center An experiment to shew that the friction of the several parts in a compound machine, may be reduced to calculation Two experiments of the friction of pulleys An account of an experiment, contrived by G. J. Gravelande, relating to the force of moving bodies, shewn to the Royal Society An account of an instrument, or machine, for changing the air in the room of sick people A calculation of the velocity of the air, moved by a new-invented centrifugal bellows of seven feet in diameter, and one foot thick within, which a man can keep in motion with very little labour, at the rate of two revolutions in one second The uses of the foregoing machine An experiment to shew, that some damps in mines may be occasioned only by the burning of candles under ground, without the addition of any noxious vapour, even when the bottom of the pit has a communication with the outward air, unless the outward air be forcibly driven in An attempt to explain the phenomenon of the horizontal moon appearing bigger when near, than when elevated many degrees above, the horizon; supported by an experiment, with an explication Account of some new statical experiments An account of some magnetical experiments made before the Royal Society, June 24, 1736, and April 21, 1737 | Author | Title | Trans. | Abridg. | |------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------|--------|---------| | Desaguliers, J. De. Some additions to the narrative about the conjunction of the ocean and Mediterranean, by a channel in France Fuller, John. Account of the new regulations in the Royal Academy of Sciences at Paris — The exact quantity of acid salts contained in acid spirits — Observations upon the dilutions and fermentations which we may call cold, because they are accompanied with a cooing of the liquors into which they pass — Account of a new thermometer — Experiments upon metals, made with the burning glass of the Duke of Orleans — Account of Mr. Seignette's sal polychores rupellensis, and some other chemical salts — Method of making soap lees and hard soap for medicinal uses — Account of a child of a monstrous size — On the effects of the vitrum antimonii ccratum Germain, St. Observations on the transit of Venus over the Sun, June 3, 1769, near Quebec Gersten, Christian Lewis. Description and use of an arithmetic machine, invented by him — A new method of calculating eclipses, particularly of the earth, and of any appulses of the Moon to planets and fixed stars — Observations on Mercury seen over the Sun, Nov. 5, 1743, at Giesa — A description of an astronomical mural quadrant freed from many inconveniences Ghislieri, Marg. Anthony. Observations made in Italy of an eclipse of the Moon, Sept. 8, 1718 Gibbons, William, M.D. An account of a red colour reduced by mixture of a sulphureous spirit with a volatile alcali Giles. Case of an uncommon dropsy from the want of a kidney; and a large sacculus that contained the water GLE GLENIE, JAMES. An account of Virginia, its situation, temperature, productions, inhabitants, and their manner of planting and ordering tobacco, &c. GMELIN, PHILIP FREDERIC. Medico-physical observations on ipecacuanha. — Observations on some imperfections of sight through compound microscopes. Experiments on the phosphorus urine. — Examination of West Ashton well water. GOOCH, BENJAMIN. Account of the cuticular glove. — On aneurisms in the thigh. — On an amputation above-knee by the single circular incision. GOODRICH, —. Account of a great number of stones found in one bladder. Account of a fireball seen in the air and an explosion heard, Dec. 11, 1741, in Kent. — Account of three mock Suns seen December 19, 1741.
